There is a gate (always closed) - do not block the gate. Cross the gate and follow an old road up to the lookout tower. The road gradually climbs. Once you reach the top, a clearing will give you some views if you are too nervous to climb up the lookout tower. It can get windy up there, so it might be a good idea to add a layer before you climb up! The lookout tower sways and may make some feel uneasy, but it is relatively safe to use. You get great 360-degree views and there are spectacular fall color in October.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7009985/from-the-lookout-tower-in-october-beautiful-fall-color", "ratings": {"rating": 4.3, "num_reviewers": 9}, "stats": {"dist": 0.8, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5294, 4947], "alt-change": [347, 0], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 12.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7015749/mountains-to-sea-trail-segment-3", "title": "Mountains-to-Sea Trail: Segment 3", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.403227,-82.753648", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7015749", "info-text": {"description": "Segment 3 is the most heavily used part of the MST within the mountains, and you are likely to encounter hikers and dog walkers at any time throughout the year. Virtually all of it is easily accessible from the Blue Ridge Parkway, and there are road crossings every few miles for most of the length. Despite its accessibility, the segment is quite rugged, with elevations ranging from 2,000 feet at the French Broad River to over 6,600 feet at the summit of Mount Mitchell.\r\n\nHighlights include:\r\n\u2022\tThe views atop 6,684-foot Mount Mitchell, the highest point east of the Mississippi River\r\n\u2022\tThe Shut-In Trail, which follows the old bridle trail from the Biltmore House to George Vanderbilt's hunting lodge near the summit of Mount Pisgah (which no longer stands, but a few remnants of which are still visible)\r\n\u2022\tThe cultural and scientific displays at the Blue Ridge Parkway Visitor Center & Headquarters near Asheville\r\n\u2022\tThe fine collection of southern art and crafts at the Folk Art Center also near Asheville\r\n\u2022\tThe ruins of Rattlesnake Lodge, a summer lodge built in 1903-4 by Asheville physician Chase Ambler\r\n\u2022\tIn early summer, the azalea and rhododendron displays at Craggy Gardens\r\n\u2022\tIn the fall, brilliant color displays that attract people from all over the country\r\n\nThe trail in Segment 3 is generally well marked with the MST blaze\u2014a 3\" white circle\u2014either painted on or affixed to trees or signposts. Within Mt. Mitchell State Park, the trails are also blazed for the state park trail system, and there are informative signs at all the major trail junctions.\r\n\nFor more information, including camping, lodging, parking, shuttles, and resupply information, as well as detailed, turn-by-turn directions, download a trail guide from the Friends of the Mountains-to-Sea Trail.\r\n\nWalt Weber and the Carolina Mountain Club have published an excellent, highly detailed, set of maps and profiles for this segment of the MST entitled Trail Profiles and Maps: From the Great Smokies to Mount Mitchell and Beyond. The book is available on Amazon or through a number of outlets in the Asheville area.\r\n\nThe trail in this segment is maintained by the Carolina Mountain Club.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7013419/view-from-the-mt-mitchell-summit", "ratings": {"rating": 4.3, "num_reviewers": 15}, "stats": {"dist": 69.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [6594, 2032], "alt-change": [10882, 12792], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 55.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7020421/mount-pisgah-trail", "title": "Mount Pisgah Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.403564,-82.754699", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7020421", "info-text": {"description": "Though the journey to the end of this trail might not seem tiring, you'll find that the trip can be strenuous. You'll begin on flat terrain that weaves through the woods just a short way away from the road. After nearly two miles of entirely pleasant hiking, you'll come to a steep incline for the last half mile of the trail. You'll have left the road at this point, and the peaceful journey more than makes up for the terrain. \r\n\nAt the end of the trail there is an awesome deck, that is great for a picnic and for taking in a beautiful view. In the fall you can see the beautiful colors of the leaves as they change. \r\n\nOnce you've enjoyed your time observing or picnicking, head back the way you came to return to your vehicle.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7021759/the-summit-of-pisgah-mtn", "ratings": {"rating": 4.1, "num_reviewers": 31}, "stats": {"dist": 2.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5688, 4876], "alt-change": [903, 112], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 22.0}},

Hilton Jr. Memorial Park. \r\n\nFrom there, you'll walk on boardwalks across a cove of Lake Hickory - a great area to look for wildlife. The trail ends at a grassy area in the park, where you can also find playgrounds, a memorial garden, many picnic areas, and other nice amenities. \r\n\nParking is available at the trailhead at Jaycee Park and Hickory City Park (1515 12th Street NW Dr. Hickory, NC 28601). {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7085063/wildcat-rock-trail", "title": "Wildcat Rock Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.473299,-82.332078", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7085063", "info-text": {"description": "The Wildcat Rock Trail features three outstanding landmarks: a stunning waterfall, breathtaking views from a rock outcrop, and a picturesque ridgeline meadow at the top of Little Bearwallow Mountain. This strenuous, 3-mile out-and-back (6 mile total) trail reaches these natural features after each mile of hiking, which allows you to customize your outing for a short hike or a long hike. \r\n\nThe Wildcat Rock Trail was formerly known as the Little Bearwallow Falls Trail. In 2018, Wildcat Rock Trail won the Coalition for Recreational Trails achievement award in the category of design and construction.\r\n\nTo access this trail, you'll park at the Upper Hickory Nut Gorge Trailhead and then cross the street. You'll begin by descending into an orchard (watch out for curious bears!), and quickly enter the forest, hiking alongside a babbling brook. This trail gains elevation quickly, but after about a mile of hiking, you'll find yourself at the foot of Little Bearwallow Falls. The 100-foot falls create a popular climbing spot most of the year, and an ice climbing spot in the winter. \r\n\nImmediately beyond Little Bearwallow Falls lies the most difficult part of the trail, a steep stone staircase that leads you around to the other side of the Falls. About two miles into the trail, you'll see a side trail leading up to Wildcat Rock. A short scramble away are some stunning views of the Hickory Nut Gorge. The trail continues for another 2.4 miles, passing through a  meadow beneath Bearwallow Mountain and ending at an expansive meadow on Bearwallow's summit.\r\n\nConserving Carolina partnered with Upper Hickory Nut Gorge conservation champions John Myers and Jane Lawson as well as the Brock family in 2013 to acquire and preserve 128 acres on the north slopes of Little Bearwallow Mountain. This is the land that most of the Wildcat Rock Trail crosses. John Myers and Jane Lawson protected an additional 38 acres of their property through a conservation easement with Conserving Carolina in 2017. The first mile of the Wildcat Rock Trail crosses this land. Now protected forever, Wildcat Rock tract is considered one of the most biodiverse locations in the Natural Heritage Inventory of Henderson County.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7066432/love-the-rocky-areas-of-this-hike-especially-above-the-falls-area", "ratings": {"rating": 4.5, "num_reviewers": 10}, "stats": {"dist": 4.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [4165, 2373], "alt-change": [1911, 214], "avg-grade": 10.0, "max-grade": 29.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7089626/trombatore-trail", "title": "Trombatore Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.460678,-82.367957", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7089626", "info-text": {"description": "The Trombatore Trail begins at the Bearwallow Gap trailhead, on the opposite side of the road as the Bearwallow Mountain trailhead. You'll pass through the Upper Brush Creek watershed on your way to the exceptionally scenic Blue Ridge Pastures.\r\n\nAfter passing the trailhead kiosk, hike down toward Upper Brush Creek via a series of switchbacks. After about a half mile, you can see a picturesque tree with a uniquely curved trunk. Only 100 yards past that, the trail passes another interesting tree. Look below you to the right to spot a giant buckeye that is the largest tree on the entire property. Its many burls may be the reason that loggers who once timbered the tract chose to leave it standing. The tree now stands more than 100 feet tall and is likely more than 150 years in age.\r\n\nAt 1.1 miles, the singletrack trail junctions with a grassy road. Turn right and follow the road uphill, following signs at several more junctions until trail resumes as a singletrack path, 1.8 miles in. Another uphill climb will take you to the grassy meadow of Blue Ridge Pastures at 2.4 miles. Turn left and hike to the summit to enjoy panoramic views of the Hickory Nut Gorge, including Bearwallow Mountain, Florence Nature Preserve, Little Pisgah Mountain, and Wildcat Rock. On a clear day, you can see Mt. Mitchell and the Black Mountains to the north.\r\n\nThe Trombatore Trail is named for the Trombatore family, who generously donated a public trail easement across their land. While this is private land, they made it open to the public to share the natural wonders of their property.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7066492/the-summit-of-blue-ridge-pastures-at-the-end-of-the-trombatore-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 7}, "stats": {"dist": 2.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3746, 3125], "alt-change": [694, 613], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 30.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7022757/wolf-rock-trail", "title": "Wolf Rock Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=36.39647,-81.052078", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7022757", "info-text": {"description": "The Wolf Rock Trail might be a strenuous climb, but the views from the top are well worthwhile. From the top, visitors will be able to gaze out over three distinct watersheds, all separated by ridgelines. Bullhead Creek, Garden Creek, and Widow's Creek drainages can all be picked out from your vantage point at the top of Wolf Rock. \r\n\nWhile you're taking your time climbing this trail, note the changing forest that surrounds the trail. The route begins in a predominantly pine forest before moving higher in elevation to a more mixed assemblage forest, and finally coming to an end in an area dominated by mature hardwoods. Especially in the fall, the colors of the leaves changing contrasts nicely with the dark greens of the pine forests. \r\n\nOnce you've taken your time to enjoy the views from the top of Wolf Rock, you can continue on the Blackjack Ridge Trail, or return the way that you came.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7024535/the-summit-of-wolf-rock-provides-great-views-of-stone-mountain-through-the-fall-", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 6}, "stats": {"dist": 1.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1955, 1561], "alt-change": [394, 89], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 23.0}},

The lower portions are made up of predominantly pine forests, though more and more hardwoods can be seen as the trail climbs to the summit of Wolf Rock. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7016563/upper-falls-trail", "title": "Upper Falls Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.592859,-81.633584", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7016563", "info-text": {"description": "From the Cicero Family Campground parking area, look for the sign to the Hemlock Nature Trail and Raven Rock Trail. The trail proceeds upward for about 1.5 miles to the trail junction for the Raven Rock Trail and the start of the Upper Falls Trail.  \r\n\nUpper Falls begins with a descent through a hardwood and pine forest for .5 miles to Jacob's Creek. Here a wet stream crossing is required through the creek. You may encounter people fly fishing up and downstream as you make your crossing. Once across the stream, you'll immediately emerge into the Upper Falls backpacking/tent only camping grounds. The trail runs through the middle of this 5 tent site camp and starts its ascent. \r\n\nThe climb is steep, at this point, and stays that way for about a mile. The path, however, is wide with a surface that is free of roots and large rocks. The trail passes through a hardwood and pine forest, up to a mountain ridge line where it provides vistas of the South Mountains in both directions. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7022773/cedar-rock-trail", "title": "Cedar Rock Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=36.387684,-81.048394", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7022773", "info-text": {"description": "This moderate route is another method of reaching the summit of Wolf Rock, and the Cedar Rock Trail seems to be a happy medium between the strenuous Wolf Rock Trail and the longer but milder Blackjack Ridge Trail. The route doesn't lead all the way to Wolf Rock but will bring hikers to the ridgeline just before the final push to the summit.\r\n\nDuring the forested portions of the trail, the tree assemblage framing the trail will be similar to both the Wolf Rock Trail and the Blackjack Ridge Trail, beginning in pines, and ending in hardwood. However, there will be more exposed travel on this route, and hikers will need to cross over some sections of bare rock on the way to the top of the ridgeline. \r\n\nCarry on your way, and you'll soon find yourself at the three-way intersection that marks the end of this route. Continue on the Wolf Rock Trail for more spectacular views, or head down the Blackjack Ridge Trail for a relaxing descent to the valley bottom.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7024535/the-summit-of-wolf-rock-provides-great-views-of-stone-mountain-through-the-fall-", "ratings": {"rating": 4.3, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 0.5, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1911, 1743], "alt-change": [169, 46], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 17.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7049973/bridal-out-and-back-trail", "title": "Bridal Out-and-Back Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=36.374427,-81.05462", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7049973", "info-text": {"description": "The trail begins coming off of the eastern end of the Bridle Loop. From here the trail heads south and then slowly twists around. At the first creek crossing (0.25 mile in), you start heading north. \r\n\nThe next half mile begins a steep rise of 150 feet which is soon matched by dropping back down where you reach the Big Sandy Creek. Continue along the creek, and you'll arrive at Lower Falls. Cool off at the falls and follow the creek until you meet the intersection with Middle Falls/Lower Falls Trail that heads to the left. Rock hop or wade across the creek and turn right here. \r\n\nFrom here, the trail changes character as it builds altitude at a steady pace, switchbacking it's way up the hill. The trees here are tall and spread out making a big canopy. At a little of 2 miles in you can hear rushing waters of a branch of the Big Sandy Creek but the thick rhododendrons keep you from seeing it. The trail twists north and straightens out; climbing steeply for the next mile.\r\n\nFrom here the trail takes a more meandering pace. The towering trees are phased out for smaller Post Oaks and some pine as the forest seems to open up. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7013160/summit-trail", "title": "Summit Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=36.331647,-81.689118", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7013160", "info-text": {"description": "The Summit Trail was completed with the help of over 6,000 hours provided by many volunteers over a five year span. The beautiful and well-maintained trail is a big part of the adventure but the breathtaking view from the top is the icing on the cake. Upon reaching the summit of Elk Knob hikers have spectacular views of The Peak, Three Top, and Bluff Mountains, Mount Jefferson, Grandfather Mountain, Mount Mitchell, Mt Rodgers (Va.), and the Iron Mountains in Virginia and Tennessee.\r\n\nLooking for a mountain 5k with a continuous, but manageable ascent? The Elk Knob Summit Trail is calling you. Follow the main gravel road through Elk Knob State Park until it dead ends at the large trailhead parking area. The Backcountry Trail descends to the left. You'll ascend the Summit Trail to the right. \r\n\nThis trail took over five years to build and you'll see why - it's the smoothest, most bomber trail in the NC mountains. Expect grades of less than 10% for the majority of the trail. You can catch your breathe and take in long distance views at an overlook around the 0.75 mile mark.  \r\n\nOn the final push, the trail steepens as you power out the last bit of vertical on perfectly spaced steps onto the old jeep trail/doubletrack. From here there are two summit options to take in: the North Summit with views of Mount Rogers and Virginia, and the South Summit with views of Grandfather Mountain, Roan Mountain, and Mount Mitchell. For a faster, albeit more knee-knocking descent, you can take the old jeep trail straight back to the parking area.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7050309/spectacular-view-and-im-not-even-at-the-top", "ratings": {"rating": 4.3, "num_reviewers": 20}, "stats": {"dist": 1.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5531, 4576], "alt-change": [955, 0], "avg-grade": 11.0, "max-grade": 25.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7055066/canebrake-trail", "title": "Canebrake Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.105306,-82.890219", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7055066", "info-text": {"description": "The Canebrake Trail, an old road, is well maintained and easy to follow. The trail itself is unremarkable, so hiking it is more about the destination than the journey. The trail ends at the Foothills Trail where the Toxaway River and Toxaway Creek empty into Lake Jocassee. Two suspension bridges mean no wading to cross Toxaway Creek or the Toxaway River. We crossed one or two small springs on the way, but bring enough water to get to the lake.\r\n\nThere are six camp sites along Toxaway Creek and lake, each with a picnic table, fire ring, and tent pad. Camping is only allowed in the designated sites and there really is no place to camp on the trail anyway. On a late Saturday night in August, there were more boaters in the camp sites than hikers, but there was plenty of room.  \r\n\nKeep in mind that what was downhill on the way in is uphill on the way out. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7103416/hickory-nut-falls-trail", "title": "Hickory Nut Falls Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.433315,-82.24981", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7103416", "info-text": {"description": "This heavily traveled tourist trail culminates with a full view of Hickory Nut Falls from a platform directly under the falls.  The Hickory Nut Falls trail may be accessed by going down the stairs from the main parking lot or directly from the lower level parking area.  About a quarter mile in continue straight past the Four Seasons Trail on the right. The Hickory Nut Falls trail itself is fairly uneventful and wide for the most part, with some moderate uphill sections, but becomes rockier towards the end as the sound of the falls increases.  Keep going past high cliff walls on the left and up the stairs to reach the platform under the falls. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7016757/mountains-to-sea-trail-segment-12", "title": "Mountains-to-Sea Trail: Segment 12", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.370337,-78.308416", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7016757", "info-text": {"description": "Segment 12 of North Carolina's 1,175-mile Mountains-to-Sea Trail traverses one of the most productive agricultural areas in North Carolina. It passes through Bentonville Battlefield, the site of the largest Civil War battle in the state, crosses three popular paddling rivers, and goes through two of Sampson County's picturesque small towns.\r\n\nThe farms of Johnston, Sampson and Cumberland counties along the route produce a diversity of products. Look for tobacco, cotton, sweet potatoes, hogs, turkeys, cattle, soybeans, and forestry. Great agricultural soils and climate, fairly flat topography, and good rainfall have led Sampson County to be ranked first in North Carolina in agricultural crops and second in livestock and poultry.\r\n\nHighlights include:\r\n\nBentonville Battlefield, now a North Carolina historic site. The trail route takes you past historical displays that help you envision the battle as it unfolded in March 1865.\r\nGreat and Little Coharie Creeks, popular paddling destinations named for the Native American tribe that is still based in Sampson County today.\r\nThe 2,100-acre White Woods Plant Conservation Preserve between Roseboro and Salemburg, which is being managed to enhance habitat for rare and endangered native plants and wildlife. The trail route follows the roads around this preserve.\r\nThe towns of Newton Grove and Roseboro. Newton Grove, first incorporated in 1879, grew up to serve the vibrant farming community in that area. Roseboro, incorporated in 1891, was built along the Cape Fear and Yadkin Valley Railroad line, which ran from Fayetteville to Wilmington.\r\nBushy Lake Natural Area, part of the NC state parks system, which is located along the trail route on Gip and Turnbull Roads in Cumberland County. \n\nThis hike is entirely on roads. Through Sampson, Bladen and Cumberland Counties, it is marked with MST blazes (a 3-inch white circle) and signs. Blazes are on the left shoulder of the road in the direction of travel, and signs are on the right side. Note that signs are often a target of theft and vandalism, and should not be relied upon exclusively for wayfinding.\r\n\nFor more information, including camping, lodging, parking, shuttles, and resupply information, as well as detailed, turn-by-turn directions, download a trail guide from the Friends of the MST.", "features": "River/Creek", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7015042/a-country-road-on-mst-segment-12b-coming-into-roseboro-photo-by-pj-wetzel-wwwpjw", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 68.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [192, 79], "alt-change": [881, 880], "avg-grade": 0.0, "max-grade": 4.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7016758/mountains-to-sea-trail-segment-13", "title": "Mountains-to-Sea Trail: Segment 13", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=34.834286,-78.632106", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7016758", "info-text": {"description": "Segment 13 of North Carolina's 1,175-mile Mountains-to-Sea Trail explores one of the most diverse and intriguing ecological areas in the nation as well as a Revolutionary War site and the resort community of White Lake.\r\n\nThe route traverses public lands that protect many \"Carolina Bays,\" elliptical depressions all aligned in a northwest to southeast direction. The bays provide habitat for many rare and endangered species, and theories abound about how they were originally formed. Some of the more famous bays, including Jones, White and Singletary, are large lakes. In other places, hikers should look for bays without standing water\u2014still with the same shape and directional alignment. The bays are named for the bay tree which grows in many of them.\r\n\nAt Turnbull Creek Educational State Forest, hikers can also learn about the naval stores industry that tapped longleaf pine for tar and turpentine until the Civil War and the role that public-land managers in Bladen County are playing today to revive the population of endangered Red-cockaded Woodpeckers.\r\n\nThe trail also features Harmony Hall Plantation, which holds one of the oldest residences in North Carolina, built before the Revolutionary War.\r\n\nThe trail through Bladen Lakes State Forest, Jones Lake State Park, and Singletary Lake State Park is marked with blazes and signs for park trails, and with the MST blaze\u2014a 3-inch white circle (in some places, a white diamond may have been used temporarily). Road portions of the segment are marked with blazes and signs. Blazes are on the left shoulder of the road in the direction of travel and signs are on the right side. Note that signs are often a target of theft and vandalism, and should not be relied upon exclusively for wayfinding. The trail in Suggs Mill Pond Game Land is not currently marked.\r\n\nFor more information, including camping, lodging, parking, shuttles and resupply information, as well as detailed, turn-by-turn directions, download a trail guide from the Friends of the Mountains-to-Sea Trail.", "features": "Lake \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7059151/cypress-shoreline", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 40.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [110, 53], "alt-change": [171, 206], "avg-grade": 0.0, "max-grade": 1.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7095037/chinqua-penn-walking-trail", "title": "Chinqua-Penn Walking Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=36.382925,-79.702934", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7095037", "info-text": {"description": "This wide gravel path trail begins on an open farm road between cow pastures. Make a left near the hay barn and continue between more pastures before finally entering the woods.\r\n\nAfter some downhill you'll come around a bend and see a 30-foot tall stone dam with five grindstones embedded in the face of it. Wooden stairs lead down to a platform viewing area. Informational signs explain about the dam, the pond, and the pump house upstream. You can also cross the dam to the other side where original stone steps lead down to the face of the dam. Some stones have started to separate from the dam and others have fallen, so watch your footing.\r\n\nOn your left (back on the trail) are some stone steps leading to an original covered picnic area with five more grindstones used as tables. Two wooden-tooth gears and a driveshaft hold up the roof. From here the trail follows the edge of the pond on a wooden walkway to the old pump house. Just upstream from the pump house is a small waterfall known as \"Little Niagara\".\r\n\nThe trail continues along the stream to the bottom of another cow pasture. Another boardwalk leads you through some woods to another pasture. There's a pond on the left, then more pastures and woods.\r\n\nOn the right are the remains of the Penn's Stew Site, where they cooked Brunswick stew for up to 100 guests at a time. The site includes a spring house, storage shed, stone tables, a fallen chimney, and informational signs, including the stew recipe.\r\n\nA little bit more open field and you're back to the car.", "features": "Historical Significance \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7072309/stone-steps-leading-to-a-grindstone-table-picnic-area-on-the-chinqua-penn-walkin", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 1.7, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [872, 727], "alt-change": [148, 147], "avg-grade": 3.0, "max-grade": 11.0}},

The entire trail is part of the statewide Mountains-to-Sea Trail, and the two trails overlap in the park. The trail starts at the small parking area across a bridge and over the Eno River. Visitors will have to park, and then retrace their steps to reach the trail. \r\n\nFrom the start, the route leads to a rock-hop crossing over Crooked Creek, and then continues east from there. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7015864/laurel-bluffs-trail-east", "title": "Laurel Bluffs Trail (East)", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=36.071579,-78.935117", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7015864", "info-text": {"description": "The eastern segment of Laurel Bluffs Trail leads from Pump Station to Guess Road, following the Eno River upstream. The entire trail is part of the statewide Mountains-to-Sea Trail, though the trails overlap through the park.  \r\n\nFrom the Pump Station, Laurel Bluffs Trail follows the Eno River downstream. There are a surprising number of hills along the trail, heading up to bluffs high above the river, then down to cross rocky draws where small tributaries flow into the river.\r\n\nAlong the way, the trail passes several points of interest including Fish Dam Island, Gebel Rock, Panther Cliffs, and the ruins of Guess Mill Dam. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7016767/mountains-to-sea-trail-segment-10", "title": "Mountains-to-Sea Trail: Segment 10", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=36.046975,-79.011312", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7016767", "info-text": {"description": "The trail starts in Orange County, following the Eno downstream in Eno River State Park to soon enter Durham County, where it goes through the history-laden West Point on the Eno Park. Approximately 10 miles later, it traverses Penny's Bend Nature Preserve, where a geological oddity causes the river to form a U-shaped bend, unusual for this area. Soon the Eno disappears as it flows into the vastness of Falls Lake. The MST now hugs the southern shore of this man-made reservoir as it winds its way in and out of coves and small creeks to end by the dam on the outskirts of Raleigh. The fact that this 77-mile footpath exists is due to a combination of serendipity and hard work: serendipity because of the creation of several large parcels of adjoining public lands, rare in North Carolina east of the mountains, and hard work due to all the Triangle-area trail enthusiasts who've made this footpath a reality.\r\n\nThe trail is well-marked with the MST blaze, a 3\" white circle. Where the MST runs concurrent with other trails, mostly in Eno River State Park, there are multiple colored markings.\r\n\nFor more information, including camping, lodging, parking, shuttles, and resupply information, as well as detailed, turn-by-turn directions, download a trail guide from the Friends of the Mountains-to-Sea Trail.", "features": "Lake \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Swimming", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7071807/beautiful-stream-flowing-into-the-eno-river", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 13}, "stats": {"dist": 76.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [467, 221], "alt-change": [2646, 2832], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 17.0}},

From the Piper-Cox Museum parking lot, follow the trail downhill until you come upon the Eno River. Lots of folks stop here to get in the water or check out the rapids. Head right and you'll have to make a choice: stay by the river or head uphill. Go right to continue uphill. Soon, you are in thick forest with a good canopy. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7014178/pinnacle-trail", "title": "Pinnacle Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.213655,-81.293419", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7014178", "info-text": {"description": "From the visitors center this trail provides and easy trail up to the ridge, but gains steepness as you approach the summit. There are also backpacking sites along the lower section, so if you need to get your backcountry fix without a long trip in, this is the place.\r\n\nBegin to the left of the Visitors Center at the Sparrow Springs Access area. The way is level for a few hundred yards, then turn left at the sign. You begin to climb easily through the woods, then the trail turns left and you soon get to the rocky ridge that defines this area. \r\n\nMake your way over several rocky sections and then drop slightly to a saddle. here you find the Turnback Trail, where you can, as the name suggests, turn back, or you can stay the course and continue. The trail ascends along the side of the hill from this point and is often off-camber. There is one switchback and then the trail begins to get steep. \r\n\nAt the sign for the Ridgeline Trail, turn right and watch your step as you climb the steepest and most eroded part. Soon enough you'll reach the rocks and the end of the official trail. The GPS track for this trail will lead you to the left and around the rocks to the area with the best view. \r\n\nThe warning signs don't lie: people have died here, and recently. Please keep young ones close and stay back from the ledges.  \r\n\nThe official site, with maps, is here. \r\n\nEnjoy!", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7011609/rocky-sections-require-trekking-poles-at-least-when-youre-carrying-a-load", "ratings": {"rating": 4.1, "num_reviewers": 7}, "stats": {"dist": 2.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1608, 886], "alt-change": [764, 42], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 19.0}},

It can also make an easy loop if you want to avoid the steep area near the top of The Pinnacle.\r\n\nThere are several distinct areas of forest and a small stream along this trail. Follow the white triangle blazes. Intersections are well-signed, but just in case, if you are returning from The Pinnacle, going downhill, turn left when you see a road ahead, this is where the Turnback Trail meets and follows the Fern Trail. After a few hundred yards, turn left again at the sign that explains why it's called the Fern Trail. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7019644/crowders-trail", "title": "Crowders Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.21375,-81.293482", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7019644", "info-text": {"description": "The Crowder's Trail is a 2.8-mile, moderate trail that winds along the base of Crowder's Mountain from the visitor's center to the Backside Trail at the Linwood Road Access. \r\n\nA full out-and-back journey on this trail amounts to a nice 5.6-mile trip. The Crowder's Trail itself winds through the pine-oak forests that are gradually being over taken by oaks. Below the summit, this trail is lightly used, offering users a nice experience. \r\n\nThe going here is much less strenuous than the hike to the summit. However, most visitors do make a nice loop out of the Crowder's Trail by connecting to two or three other trails in the area, most of which take visitors to the iconic summit of Crowder's Mountain. \r\n\nThe Crowder's Trail starts at the Crowder's Mountain State Park visitors center at the Sparrow Springs Access. Please note that on weekends, this parking lot fills quickly and visitors arriving later in the day might have to drive to a different lot to access the park. \r\n\nThe trail meanders for a while through the forest before crossing the road. The trail continues to the junction of the Rocktop Trail and Crowders Trail. Staying on the Crowders Trail will take visitors along the base of Crowders Mountain for an enjoyable and moderate hike through the pine-oak forest. \r\n\nThis is a less-traveled trail and may offer a little more peace and quiet with a lot of nice hammock-ing stops along the way.  Most choose to complete a loop and take the strenuous Rocktop Trail up to the summit of Crowders Mountain. The trail is very rocky but the views are well worth the effort. \r\n\nFrom the Rocktop Trail, visitors have the choice to head down the Tower Trail (which is a gravel road), connecting to the Backside Trail and then back to the Crowders Trail OR staying on the Rocktop Trail to the very popular overlook with views of Charlotte then down connecting back to the Crowders Trail. \r\n\nConnecting to the other trails heading up to the summit makes for a very challenging loop and staying on the Crowders Trail can be a rewarding route as well, especially for visitors who seek a less strenuous outing.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7025229/dramatic-views-from-crowder-mountain", "ratings": {"rating": 3.9, "num_reviewers": 14}, "stats": {"dist": 2.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1177, 851], "alt-change": [355, 63], "avg-grade": 3.0, "max-grade": 13.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7018831/summit-loop-trail", "title": "Summit Loop Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=36.257601,-77.881626", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7018831", "info-text": {"description": "Summit Loop Trail is a segment of the trail system at Medoc Mountain State Park. This trail is accessed via Stream Loop and then Discovery Loop Trail. You'll hike nearly a mile or so on these trails, mostly parallel to Fisher Creek....which appears to be a deep creek/small river....not seen to be passable on foot. You must follow these trails to access a bridge , which gives access to Summit Loop on the other side of the creek.  I wish the park had a bridge earlier to access Summit Loop. \r\n\nOnce across the bridge, you are faced with 3 trail options, straight ahead and also to right both being the start/end point of Summit Loop. I chose to go straight ahead which created a clockwise trek of Summit Loop. The trail quickly ascends up to about 300 feet of elevation, including some steps built into the trail to ease access. At the top, two benches are conveniently placed for visitors. I had hoped for a scenic overlook but none was seen or found. \r\n\nThe path from that point is more of a dirt road, wide and clean. The trail from this point is nearly flat with forest sloping away on both sides. Look for a small cemetery on the right side... this is your path to return. No real signage... I missed it the first time... only a small stub post with arrow to mark trail bearing off to your right. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7041869/mountain-laurel-loop", "title": "Mountain Laurel Loop", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.455022,-78.908688", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7041869", "info-text": {"description": "Mountain Laurel Loop is the first of several mountain bike trails planned for Raven Rock State Park. It's a singletrack trail that crosses several wooden bridges, and the entire loop is about 6.5 miles long. The loop passes through forests that include both evergreen and deciduous trees, so it's shady during the spring, summer, and early fall. The trail isn't technically challenge but changing elevations will still give you a good workout.\r\n\nMountain Laurel Loop trail is open to hikers and bikers who are required to travel in opposite directions around the loop. There's a short access trail before the loop begins which allows two-way traffic, and a sign at the beginning of the actual loop shows which direction to walk or ride depending on the day of the week. \r\n\nThe highest elevation is at the beginning of the trail, so no matter which direction you travel, you'll start by hiking downhill and finish on an uphill stretch. When you hike in a clockwise direction, the first third of the trail is mostly downhill with several fairly steep sections. The remaining two thirds of the trail ascend gradually, with a mix of uphill and level sections. When you hike in a counterclockwise direction, the first part of the trail descends gradually allowing you to breeze through the first four miles with very little effort. However, the last few miles are mostly uphill.\r\n\nParking for the trail is located in a grassy field away from the main parking area for Raven Rock State Park. To find the trailhead, turn right onto Moccasin Branch Road before you pass through the main entrance to the state park. Drive about 0.25 miles and look for the sign to the mountain bike trailhead. Two portable toilets are located near the beginning of the trail.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.7, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 6.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [349, 200], "alt-change": [353, 365], "avg-grade": 2.0, "max-grade": 11.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7042919/raven-rock-loop-trail", "title": "Raven Rock Loop Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.462171,-78.912219", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7042919", "info-text": {"description": "This trail begins from the parking lot and passes a small restroom. Immediately, it becomes enshrouded in a beautiful canopy of woods. The trail is wide and well kept through this section as it follows its characteristic orange-circle blazes. Along the way, expect to see many other people. \r\n\nIn about 0.8 miles, the trail reaches a fork, where the left option takes you onto the Fish Traps Trail and the right continues on Raven Rock. Staying to the right, continue to follow the orange blazes. There are a few benches and pull off areas for resting. The entire trail is full of tall pine trees and begins to follow the Little Creek. There are built-in stairs at a few of the steeper areas, making it a great trail for jogging. There is a scenic overlook in about 0.5 miles after the fork that consists of a manmade structure that gives views of the Cape Fear River.\r\n\nAfter 1 mile is another trail junction with Little Creek Loop and the view to Raven Rock itself. Continuing toward Raven Rock leads to a wooden stairway that goes downward toward a beautiful rock-and-cliff formation on the bank of the Cape Fear River. The river bank has plenty of hiking area to view the cliffs further along. Many families and other trekkers convene here, so it can get crowded and loud, but if you hike to the right along the river bank there are many more secluded areas to stop and relax. \r\n\nTo continue along the loop, you must double-back up the stairs to the junction with Little Creek Loop. From there, the Raven Rock Loop Trail continues under its shrouds of greenery back to the parking area.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7002020/frozen-waterfall", "ratings": {"rating": 4.4, "num_reviewers": 11}, "stats": {"dist": 2.2, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [347, 200], "alt-change": [175, 176], "avg-grade": 3.0, "max-grade": 10.0}},

Many picnic tables ring the parking lot. The hours are different from the park proper which closes at 5 pm.\r\n\nIron Ore Belt Access' hours are:\r\n     November through February: 8am - 6pm\r\n     March, April, May, September, October: 8am - 8pm\r\n     June through August: 8am - 9pm\r\n     CLOSED CHRISTMAS DAY\r\n\nThe Great Blue Heron Loop does not start at the parking lot. Instead, it is accessed via a .2 mile connector trail designated by white circle blazes which ends at the first power line cut you come to. This is the beginning of the loop. Signs direct you to a clockwise trek as you begin to follow the orange square blazes. There are no signs discouraging a counter-clockwise direction but it may be difficult to find the start in that direction.\r\n\nThe entire trail is very user-friendly. There are no major climbs or descents. It passes the power cut in a different location, crosses a small field, follows an employee access track along the way, but mostly visitors will enjoy seeing lots of trees. Undergrowth is mostly grasses, so the trail feels much more open than you'd think.\r\n\nNOTE: About half-way through the trail, you'll see on a small rise above the trail with picnic benches. It travels along the foot of the cliffs and ledges to the west of the Little Pinnacle. The ledge springs is just a trickle of water, but the trail below the cliffs are beautiful. It is easier to begin below the picnic area and to end below Little Pinnacle at the Jomeokee Trail.\r\n\nThe trail descends through the picnic area following the edge of the cliffs, providing many opportunities to view the NC Piedmont from the rock outcroppings. The trail takes a hairpin turn left at the junction with the Grindstone Trail. Be careful to stay on the Ledge Springs Trail to follow the loop back to the Big Pinnacle. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7013381/grindstone-trail", "title": "Grindstone Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=36.342169,-80.464013", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7013381", "info-text": {"description": "This is a moderately sloped trail that meanders through the woods surrounding Pilot Mountain to the summit. Start the trail across the road from the park office. As you're crossing the road, the trail leads off to the right. The trail then continues up through the woods to a stone building where you'll cross the main park road and head out towards the family campground. \r\n\nAfter reaching the campground, the trail continues up the mountain through the woods to the summit. The trail will reach a junction with the Mountain Trail at 1.4 miles. Continue to follow the blue circle blazes up the mountain. Next the trail joins with the yellow blazed Ledge Springs Trail. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7013776/mountains-to-sea-trail-segment-7", "title": "Mountains-to-Sea Trail: Segment 7", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=36.267836,-80.496011", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7013776", "info-text": {"description": "Segment 7 begins in the west at Pilot Mountain State Park, making a near-complete loop around the mountain. East of Pilot Mountain, the MST joins the Sauratown Trail, one of the earliest long-distance trails in the state. Winding through farmland, forests, and country roads, this trail skirts the northern flank of Sauratown Mountain. The trail is unusual in that it is mostly on private lands, and is open to trail users through the generosity of many individual landowners. As you navigate the trail, please be respectful.\r\n\nAt its eastern end, Segment 7 enters Hanging Rock State Park, the third-oldest state park in North Carolina. In the park, the MST passes within a few feet of the summit of Moore's Knob, the highest point in the Sauratown Mountains. The views from the summit fire tower are spectacular! From the rocky slopes of Moore's Knob, the trail descends through oak-hickory forest to Hanging Rock Lake, popular for swimming and boating in the summer and home to a CCC-built pavilion and bathhouse, and on to its eastern end at the Hanging Rock State Park Visitor Center.\r\n\nThis segment provides a sense of isolation that is rare in the Piedmont. There are no towns or stores on the segment, and only a few businesses of any sort. At the same time, much of the trail passes through working farmland, even within a few feet of active farm buildings. The nearest towns for resupply or lodging are Pilot Mountain, about 3 miles north of Pilot Mountain State Park; King, about 8 miles south on US 52; and Danbury, which MST Segment 8 passes through about 4 miles east of the eastern end of Segment 7.\r\n\nIn contrast to the majority of the MST, most of Segment 7 is open to horseback riders, and equestrians make up a large portion of the trail's users and advocates. All of the Sauratown Trail is equestrian trail, and the Corridor Section of Pilot Mountain State Park and the Ruben Mountain Trail (also marked as Tory's Den Trail) in the western part of Hanging Rock State Park are both open to horses. Visitors should be aware of the potential of encountering equestrians and that horses always have the right-of-way. When encountering equestrians, those on foot should calmly greet the rider and avoid quick movements to keep from frightening the horse.\r\n\nThe MST and Sauratown Trail in Segment 7 is generally very well marked with the MST blaze\u2014a 3\" white circle\u2014and Sauratown Trail signs. In a few locations, where trail is newly designated or trees have fallen, there may be gaps in the blazing, but these are rare, and the Sauratown Trails Association regularly replaces them. Because the trail is designed for equestrian use, the blazes are often higher than expected on a pedestrian-only trail. The sections of trail within Pilot Mountain and Hanging Rock State Parks, in addition to the white MST blazes, also have a second set of colored blazes corresponding to the state park trail systems.\r\n\nFor more information, including camping, lodging, parking, shuttles, and resupply information, as well as detailed, turn-by-turn directions, download a trail guide from the Friends of the Mountains-to-Sea Trail.\r\n\nThe Sauratown Trail is maintained by the Sauratown Trails Association, and the portion of Segment 7 within the state parks is maintained by Friends of the Sauratown Mountains. Both organizations hold regular trail workdays. As a result, this segment is built to very high standards, and it is a joy to explore.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Swimming \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7010804/view-from-the-observation-tower-on-moores-know-hanging-rock-state-park", "ratings": {"rating": 3.6, "num_reviewers": 10}, "stats": {"dist": 37.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2524, 861], "alt-change": [4646, 3803], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 43.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7013837/mountain-trail", "title": "Mountain Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=36.348703,-80.477246", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7013837", "info-text": {"description": "The Mountain Trail wraps around the western, southern and eastern flanks of Pilot Mountain. The MST Segment 7: Sauratown Mountains follows this trail as it travels through Pilot Mountain State Park. The trail is marked with Red Circle Blazes. \r\n\nThe trail begins at a trail intersection with the Grindstone Trail about 1/2 way up Pilot Mountain. The trail follows a fire line for about 1 mile as it rounds the northwest corner of Pilot Mountain. The trail is level and well graded. \r\n\nAfter a mile, the trail becomes rockier, passing through several impressive boulder fields. The trail climbs to 1600 feet before descending the mountain as it crosses the southern slopes. \r\n\nAt the 3.5 mile mark, the MST Segment 7: Sauratown Mountains turns to the right to follow the Mountain Trail Connector to its junction with the Corridor Trail at the parking area at Pinnacle Hotel Road. The Mountain Trail continues on its journey around the eastern slopes of Pilot Mountain crossing several small streams in this section. The trail ends at the junction with the Grassy Ridge Trail near the Visitor Center.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Minor Issues"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7011418/boulders-along-the-mountain-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 3.2, "num_reviewers": 5}, "stats": {"dist": 4.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1610, 1122], "alt-change": [282, 642], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 14.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7003827/sycamore-trail", "title": "Sycamore Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.871934,-78.760906", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7003827", "info-text": {"description": "This trail is located on the northern section of Umstead State Park with access from Glenwood Ave (Hwy 70). To access the trail, drive to the lower of two parking lots after passing the visitor center. From either parking area take the paved trail (Potts Brach Trail) south and follow the signs for Sycamore Trail. The actual trailhead is located between two shelters and is marked with Blue Triangles. The trail is similar to a lasso in shape and, in this instance, the lower section is done in a counter-clockwise direction.\n\nThe trail begins with a nice downhill that leads to Pots Branch Creek. Also, this hill makes for a nice finish at the end! From this point, the trail is mostly steady climb or descent with a pine needle/packed dirt base. There are a few sections where wash out has occurred and exposed rocks and roots. \n\nThe lasso section begins about 2 miles into the trail and going right continues downhill toward Sycamore Creek. This is a great chance to relax and let your pet, if adventuring with one, cool in the creek! The trail follows this creek for close to two miles and will cross over Graylyn Trail (Bridal Trail) for the first time. \n\nOnce the trail splits away there is a climb up from the creek to reach Graylyn Trail for the 2nd time. This section of the trail tends to hold water and has a few muddy sections. After crossing Graylyn Trail, you'll reach the split in the trail. Follow the sign that says Parking and make your way back to the trailhead.\n\nIn summary, the trail is not very technical with a few sections that have a lot of tree roots. The footing is consistent for the most part with exception to the few sections where washout and tree roots are exposed.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7002698/view-on-the-sycamore-trail-loop-umstead", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 22}, "stats": {"dist": 4.9, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [452, 266], "alt-change": [311, 319], "avg-grade": 2.0, "max-grade": 9.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7011689/south-turkey-creek-multiuse-trail", "title": "South Turkey Creek Multiuse Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.846409,-78.724444", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7011689", "info-text": {"description": "This trail connects two entrances to Umstead State Park, from the Ebenezer Church Road Bridge gate in the southeastern part of the park to the intersection of Reedy Creek Road and Trenton Road gate on the southern side of the park. There is parking at the Ebenezer Church Road Bridge gate, but not at the Reedy Creek Road and Trenton Road gate. \r\n\nTo access the trail, start at the parking lot at the Ebenezer Church Road entrance (5407 Ebenezer Church Road). The park generally is open only during daylight hours, but parking at this entrance is available even after official park hours. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7011690/cedar-ridge-multiuse-trail", "title": "Cedar Ridge Multiuse Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.846387,-78.724516", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7011690", "info-text": {"description": "The Cedar Ridge Trail begins near the Ebenezer Church Road Bridge Gate to Umstead Park and provides a connection to the main Reedy Creek Multiuse Trail that traverses the park. It is a fine gravel road surface that is about doubletrack wide with a gradual ascent about 1.5 miles in length to reach the Reedy Creek MUT. \r\n\nAt the very beginning, you'll need to cross Sycamore Creek. During low water flows, the creek can be crossed with good balance and dry feet on stepping stones; it is normally about 15 feet wide. At higher water flows, I prefer to bush-whack south to cross on one of the downed trees that currently (fall 2015) span the creek. The second tree is much wider and easier to cross on than the first tree you'll encounter during your bush-whack.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7008641/final-leg-of-south-turkey-creek-trail-after-finishing-turkey-creek-cedar-ridge-l", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 1.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [394, 236], "alt-change": [163, 13], "avg-grade": 2.0, "max-grade": 11.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7015916/sals-branch-trail", "title": "Sal's Branch Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.880931,-78.758427", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7015916", "info-text": {"description": "Sal's Branch Trail starts at the park office from the Crabtree Creek entrance to the park (US-70). The trail leads down to the gravel parking lot behind the park office and then heads into the woods. You'll follow along the small stream for which the trail is named, but unless it has rained recently, there isn't usually much water. In about a half-mile from the start, a spur trail splits and goes right towards the family campground.\r\n\nAfter this point, the trail loops around and starts heading towards the south. Although there are some minor ups and downs, the elevation change on this trail is minimal, making it a good option for all ability and fitness levels. The trail crosses a service road and soon you should be able to get glimpses of Big Lake through the trees.\r\n\nEventually, the trail comes out of the woods at a powerline clearing near the boat house. Turn left to head back into the woods and follow the trail back to the start. The trail crosses the service road once more, and you should be able to see and hear vehicles on Umstead Parkway not far to the east of the trail. At the end the trail comes out at the gravel parking lot below the visitor center. This trail is Umstead's TRACK Trail, part of the Kids in Parks Program to encourage outdoor activity. The trail features interpretive signs and a self-guided brochure to learn more about nature. The trailhead is at the first parking lot after the visitor center, the same as the trailhead for Pott's Branch Trail.\r\n\nFrom the trailhead, bear left to take the loop in a clockwise direction. This is a great spot to stop for a break, take a picture, or climb around on the rocks. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7015919/inspiration-trail", "title": "Inspiration Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.838908,-78.760233", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7015919", "info-text": {"description": "Inspiration Trail is a short interpretive trail in the Reedy Creek section of the park. The trailhead is along Company Mill Trail, just down the first hill past the picnic shelters. Inspiration Trail splits to the left and makes a short loop. Benches are provided along the trail to rest and enjoy the natural scenery. Tree identification signs help visitors learn about the different species of trees growing in a Piedmont forest.\r\n\nThe trail initially follows a small intermittent stream then curves around to higher ground on the steep slopes above Crabtree Creek. These south-facing slopes have a cooler climate than the surrounding areas and support the growth of more mountainous flora such as mountain laurel. The unique climate and ecology of this area has been recognized as Crabtree Shrub Slopes Natural Area. In about a quarter-mile, the trail loops back to the beginning. Turn left to continue on Company Mill Trail for a longer trip or turn right to head back to the picnic area.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7072380/straight-for-company-mill-trail-to-the-left-for-inspiration-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 0.3, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [367, 329], "alt-change": [38, 38], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 7.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7015920/loblolly-trail", "title": "Loblolly Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.836323,-78.75928", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7015920", "info-text": {"description": "The Loblolly Trail is the only one-way (not a loop) trail in the park, so keep in mind that your total distance will be double for out and back.  The trailhead is at the northeast corner of the parking lot at the Reedy Creek section of the park. It is about 3 miles one way to the park boundary; the sign at the trailhead that says the distance is only 2 miles is incorrect.\r\n\nThe trail starts past the picnic area and soon passes the Young Cemetery, one of several old cemeteries in the park. The trail is initially flat, but in about a half-mile the trail bears right heads down towards Reedy Creek. The trail used to continue straight to a footbridge over the creek. When this bridge was washed out in a storm, the park rerouted the trail in 2015. You may be able to see the remnants of the old trail.  The trail crosses Reedy Creek on large stones and then heads back up to a ridgeline. Once up, the trail then heads down into the next drainage crossing on a wooden footbridge and then goes up and down through some long switchbacks. After the switchbacks, the trail gradually heads up to Reedy Creek Multiuse Trail.\r\n\nAcross Reedy Creek Multiuse Trail, the trail heads back into the woods, leading down past a small pond. Past the pond, the trail gradually heads up to the next intersection at South Turkey Creek Multiuse Trail. Once across this gravel road, the last half-mile of the trail gradually leads down to the park boundary. The trail continues out of the park as the Richland Creek Trail, part of Raleigh's Capital Area greenway, leading through Schenck Forest and finally the RBC Center and Carter-Finley Stadium.\r\n\nIf you're not inclined to follow the trail all the way to its terminus at the stadium, once you reach the park boundary, simply retrace your steps to return to your starting point.", "features": "Lake \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7015146/young-fern-fiddleheads-growing-along-loblolly-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 3.8, "num_reviewers": 10}, "stats": {"dist": 3.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [447, 279], "alt-change": [261, 376], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 10.0}},

The trailhead is off of Graylyn Drive, just off Ebenezer Church Road in North Raleigh. Note that there is no parking here, this is an entrance for pedestrians and bicyclists.  \r\n\nThe trail starts beyond the gate and leads in a southerly direction into the park. Within the first half mile, you'll pass the King Family Cemetery. The King Family was one of the wealthiest families who lived in the area prior to the park's construction and so have one of the nicest cemeteries. Past the cemetery is the access to Sycamore Trail and the multi-use trailhead parking lot.\r\n\nShortly past the access to the parking lot, North Turkey Creek Multiuse Trail splits to the left. Continue on Graylyn Multiuse Trail to a powerline clearing and the trail curves to the left and heads down towards Sycamore Creek. The trail leads across the creek on a scenic stone bridge, passing an intersection with Sycamore Trail before the bridge and then Company Mill Trail immediately after the bridge. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7016192/north-turkey-creek-multiuse-trail", "title": "North Turkey Creek Multiuse Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.864152,-78.748016", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7016192", "info-text": {"description": "North Turkey Creek Trail starts by splitting from Graylyn Multiuse Trail just south of the Multiuse Trail parking. Turn left to get on the trail. The trail begins heading down gradually towards Turkey and Sycamore Creeks. Most of the hills are gradual, but a few parts are pretty steep, especially right before and after the bridge over a tributary of Sycamore Creek. Be aware that bicyclists use this trail and they will be going pretty fast heading down the hills. As you head down toward the creek, you can see the Sycamore Trail just below.\r\n\nAfter crossing the bridge, the trail heads up and then follows a ridgeline between Sycamore and Turkey Creeks. The trail is roughly parallel to Ebenezer Church Road. The park has constructed walls along portions of the trail to prevent erosion and keep users on the trail. There are good wildflower viewing opportunities here, including beautiful passionflower. In about 2 miles, the trail comes out very close to the road - you can see it and hear traffic at this point. The trail will end roughly at the confluence of Sycamore and Turkey Creeks. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7016193/reedy-creek-lake-trail", "title": "Reedy Creek Lake Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.839608,-78.753603", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7016193", "info-text": {"description": "The Reedy Creek Lake Trail begins off Reedy Creek Parkway just before the rangers' residences.  However, there is no parking here.  Instead, park at the Reedy Creek entrance off Harrison Avenue and make your way down the road to the trailhead.  Be sure to stay on the road and trail as you'll be passing private homes.\r\n\nThe trail is a dirt road and starts out heading through a wooded area.  In about a quarter-mile, to the left of the trail, visitors will see the ruins of an old building, probably an old farm house from before the park's creation. Unfortunately, this structure isn't in the Stories in Stone book, so no one's really sure what used to be here.  \r\n\nContinuing on the trail, it will start to open up as it approaches it's namesake - Reedy Creek Lake.  This small man-made lake is very scenic, especially in the fall when the leaves change.  Fishing in the lake is permitted, but swimming is not. \r\n\nPast the lake, the trail ends at Reedy Creek Multiuse Trail. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7016760/mountains-to-sea-trail-segment-15", "title": "Mountains-to-Sea Trail: Segment 15", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=34.551969,-77.811351", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7016760", "info-text": {"description": "Segment 15 of North Carolina's 1,175-mile Mountains-to-Sea Trail takes MST travelers through the Onslow Bight, formed where the coast makes a shallow bend or \"bight\" between Cape Lookout and Cape Fear. With its barrier islands, marshes, riverine wetlands, pocosins, and longleaf pine savannas, the Onslow Bight is considered one of the most ecologically diverse areas in the United States. \r\n\nThese natural communities provide habitat for rare plants and animals, including several species that are found nowhere else in the world. The pocosins and longleaf pine forests are critical habitat for nesting and foraging red-cockaded woodpeckers, while the delicate barrier islands are essential habitat for sea turtle and water bird nesting. The area is one of the primary conservation priorities for many government and nonprofit agencies.\r\n\nHighlights include:\r\n\nHolly Shelter Game Land, where hikers will see vast expanses of pocosin recovering from a major peat fire in 2011, as well as savannas of lush grasses and native plants flourishing under towering longleaf pines.\r\nThe Onslow County Environmental Education Center's \"Discover Onslow\" exhibit, a great way to learn about the ecology, flora, and fauna of the Onslow Bight\r\nStones Creek Game Land, nestled in Camp Lejeune, which provides a scenic walk past lakes and pine woods\r\nThe Lejeune Memorial Gardens, with moving tributes to our nation's servicemen and women\r\nCrossing the White Oak River to enter the little community of Stella on the outskirts of the Croatan National Forest \n\nThe trails through Holly Shelter and Stones Creek Game Lands are marked with the MST blaze, a 3-inch white circular marker. There are also signs at certain places in Stones Creek Game Land.\r\n\nRoad portions of this segment are marked with blazes and signs. Blazes are on the left shoulder of the road in the direction of travel, and signs are on the right side. Note that signs are often a target of theft and vandalism, and should not be relied upon exclusively for wayfinding.\r\n\nFor more information, including camping, lodging, parking, shuttles, and resupply information, as well as detailed, turn-by-turn directions, download a trail guide from the Friends of the Mountains-to-Sea Trail.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Swimming \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7030088/the-bridge-over-the-marsh-in-surf-city-and-the-walking-bridge-from-soundside-par", "ratings": {"rating": 3.5, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 94.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [70, 0], "alt-change": [576, 606], "avg-grade": 0.0, "max-grade": 3.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7016762/mountains-to-sea-trail-segment-17", "title": "Mountains-to-Sea Trail: Segment 17", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=34.760777,-76.761679", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7016762", "info-text": {"description": "Segment 17 of North Carolina's 1,175-mile Mountains-to-Sea Trail takes hikers \"Down East\" to see the North River, small fishing towns that face the Core Sound, and the 14,500 acres of the Cedar Island National Wildlife Refuge.\r\n\nHeading east from Oyster Point Campground, the southern terminus of the Neusiok Trail, hikers experience a short roadside glimpse of the beauty and variety of the Croatan National Forest before crossing the North River to enter a part of Carteret County traditionally referred to as \"Down East.\" Fishing, particularly for shrimp and blue crabs, is a mainstay of the economy.\r\n\nLook for the entrance to the NC Coastal Federation's North River Wetlands Preserve along US 70. NCCF is restoring this 6,000-acre farm back to its original state\u2014forested, freshwater and tidal wetlands\u2014in order to improve the water quality of degraded downstream estuaries and reopen these waters for shellfishing. In the future, when a bridge and boardwalk is built near the headwaters of the North River, the MST will traverse this property for more than eight miles. Hikers can visit the preserve now by registering and paying a $5.00 fee at the entrance.\r\n\nThe trail route continues through a string of Down East communities fronting Core Sound. Hikers are rarely out of sight of bays, estuaries, and wetlands as they walk through Otway, Smyrna, Williston, Davis and Stacy.\r\n\nThe route veers off US 70 onto NC 12 as it nears the Cedar Island National Wildlife Refuge, where the only people on the road are visiting the refuge or heading for the ferry. Here vast marshlands stretch toward the horizon, dotted with occasional \"islands\" of trees. Two hundred and seventy species of birds, 91 of amphibians and reptiles, and 35 mammals are known to live in the refuge, including breeding black rails, a bird species of special concern.\r\n\nHighlights include:\r\n\nThe diversity of native plants and wildlife\u2014first in the Croatan National Forest and then along the sounds, rivers, marshes and estuaries of North Carolina's inner banks.\r\nThe welcoming people who live in the small villages \"down east\" along the Core Sound. \n\nThere are no MST signs or blazes in this segment.\r\n\nFor more information, including camping, lodging, parking, shuttles and resupply information, as well as detailed, turn-by-turn directions, download a trail guide from the Friends of the Mountains-to-Sea Trail.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Swimming \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.3, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 49.9, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [19, 1], "alt-change": [118, 127], "avg-grade": 0.0, "max-grade": 1.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7016768/mountains-to-sea-trail-segment-18", "title": "Mountains-to-Sea Trail: Segment 18", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.01868,-76.314138", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7016768", "info-text": {"description": "This hike covers Segment 18 of North Carolina's 1,175-mile Mountains-to-Sea Trail. From the secluded beaches of Ocracoke Island to the tourist bustle of Nags Head, it captures the many aspects of North Carolina's easternmost parts. These barrier islands, or \"banks,\" are rich with history, wildlife and scenery. They are also the site of some of the most extreme weather in the country. Situated as it is\u2014far out in the ocean, where two major ocean currents collide\u2014the region has earned its nickname, \"The Graveyard of the Atlantic.\"\r\n\nHighlights include:\r\n\nOcracoke Village, a quaint and quiet town at the western end of the segment\r\nCape Hatteras National Seashore, encompassing the beaches for nearly the entire segment\r\nThe Ocracoke pony pens, which hold the descendants of a horse herd that once roamed on the island\r\nThe Graveyard of the Atlantic Museum, which tells the story of the over 2,000 shipwrecks off the coast of North Carolina\r\nThe Open Ponds Trail, a sandy track through maritime forest near Buxton Woods\r\nCape Hatteras Lighthouse, at 208 feet the tallest brick lighthouse in North America and the most recognized symbol of the Outer Banks; it is open for climbing in the summer\r\nThe historic Chicamacomico Life-Saving Station, the original site of the forerunners to the U.S. Coast Guard, which is now a museum\r\nPea Island National Wildlife Refuge, a renowned haven for waterfowl, especially in the winter\r\nThe historic Oregon Inlet Life-Saving Station\r\nJennette's Pier in Nags Head, a 1,000-foot fishing pier that is now part of the North Carolina Aquarium\r\nJockey's Ridge State Park, the largest and highest dune complex in the eastern United States\r\n\nThe western end of this segment is at the Cedar Island Ferry Terminal and the eastern end is at the highest point on the dunes at Jockey's Ridge State Park. The segment includes 82.2 miles of trail plus two ferry rides; the listed mileage includes the ferry rides and thus is greater than the actual hiking mileage.\r\n\nThere are MST blazes\u2014a 3-inch white circle\u2014on the trail in Jockey's Ridge State Park and a few places in the Buxton Woods area. In addition, there are a few blazes along the beach portions of the trail, mainly at the dune line where the trail leaves the beach; however, these are often destroyed by storms, so they should not be relied upon. Finally, there are mileposts on the Open Ponds Trail in the Buxton Woods area and every 0.5 mile on the beach on Ocracoke Island.\r\n\nFor more information, including camping, lodging, parking, shuttles and resupply information, as well as detailed, turn-by-turn directions, download a trail guide from the Friends of the Mountains-to-Sea Trail.", "features": "Swimming \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7015294/historic-oregon-inlet-life-saving-station-on-mst-segment-18-photo-by-pj-wetzel-w", "ratings": {"rating": 3.7, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 121.4, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [58, -23], "alt-change": [377, 320], "avg-grade": 0.0, "max-grade": 6.0}},
