{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7089661/great-wall-489", "title": "Great Wall #489", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.154956,-83.020143", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7089661", "info-text": {"description": "Trail begins at either the intersection with Granny Burrell Falls Trail #486 or Big Green #487 trail depending on which direction it is done. This trail is mostly flat, except for the uppermost portion that adjoins Big Green trail. This upper section has 4 sets of wooden steps, a wooden bridge, and various rock steps cut into the stone trail surface. The upper section of trail passes through hardwood  forest and Rhododendron tunnels, and the lower section passes through lowland pine forest where it has plenty of open areas where camping is permitted. \r\n\nThere is a large group shelter at the intersection with Granny Burrell Falls Trail #486. This trail is often very wet and muddy, with some sections impassable after heavy rains unless you wade through ankle deep water/mud. The trail is named after the rock face of Big Green Mountain, which parallels the trail on the north section near Granny Burrell Falls Trail #486. Unfortunately the rock face is barely visible in the Winter, and not visible at all in the spring, summer, and fall months when there is foliage on the trees.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7065733/view-of-the-great-wall-in-the-winter", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 1.5, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [4035, 3700], "alt-change": [7, 342], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 21.0}},

The direction changes depending on the day. In either direction, you must climb at first, but the downhill is a really fun. You'll also enjoy views of Lake Lure and Youngs Mountain along the way, especially in winter.\r\n\nHeading in a counterclockwise direction, the climb is shorter but steeper. The top of the climb is about 1.5 miles in, measured from the parking lot. One section is very steep with stacked switchbacks up a ridge. After that, it is mostly downhill through a really nice forest and some boulder fields.\r\n\nThere is a one-mile out-and-back Buffalo Creek Park Extension that breaks off the loop a little after the peak of the main climb. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7043217/purser-hulsey-park-trail", "title": "Purser-Hulsey Park Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.129385,-80.683876", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7043217", "info-text": {"description": "The Purser-Hulsey Park Trail opened in mid-2017 with a roughly 1.5-mile main trail. Since then, a couple of side loops - Enchanted Forest (~0.5mi) and Backside Loop (~3mi) - have been added increasing the potential total mileage to about 4.5 miles.\r\n\nThe trailhead is off of Phillips Road at trail kiosk to the back of the parking lot - the community garden is very noticable from the road. It's multi-use with bikers & walkers/runners, with recommendation to traverse in opposite directions for safety. \r\n\nThe trail is beginner friendly with minimal elevation change and opportunities to shorten distance even from the 1.5-mile main loop. Also, there are seating benches at points along the main loop providing an opportunity to rest and sit in natural setting.\r\n\nThe natural undulation of some of the drainage ravines adds a little fun to the hike.\r\n\nIt should also be noted that the trail is maintained by the Tarheel Trailblazers Mountain Bike Club -   tarheeltrailblazers.com \n\nThe community of visitors have taken things a step further with painted rocks - visitors are encouraged to find and move the rocks along the trail and even to bring in your own painted rock.", "features": "River/Creek", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7069715/purser-hulsey-backside-loop-biker-entrance", "ratings": {"rating": 3.5, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 1.3, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [777, 722], "alt-change": [70, 73], "avg-grade": 2.0, "max-grade": 10.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7043435/haw-river-trail-saxapahaw-section", "title": "Haw River Trail: Saxapahaw Section", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.946207,-79.319605", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7043435", "info-text": {"description": "The extension of this trail is relatively new and is supposed to go even further in the future. From the parking lot in Saxapahaw, head down hill past the main building with the beer and the ballroom. Find the stairs that head to the river. \r\n\nFrom there, you simply hike along the river down stream. The first section of forest you pass through is rich with bird life. Continue along the trail over some sturdy repurposed bridges. \r\n\nThe forest first opens up for the power line easement. After re-entering the forest, you next come upon some lovely open farmland. In the distance you can see an organic chicken farm with some attentive Great Pyrenees dogs guarding the flock. From here, you enter a mixed beech and oak forest and cross some newer wood bridges. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7051008/weed-patch-mountain-trail", "title": "Weed Patch Mountain Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.482787,-82.190962", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7051008", "info-text": {"description": "This award-winning multi-use trail explores the rugged and mountainous terrain of the wilderness area of Buffalo Creek Park. The trail winds through old growth forest, passing by streams and climbing to several stunning viewpoints. Highlights along the trail include Trout Creek, Grey Rock, Flapjack Rock, Tunnel Trail (which offers climbing access), and Eagle Rock.\r\n\nAnother interesting feature of this trail is the evidence left behind from the Party Rock Fire of 2016. The fire occurred during the construction of the Weed Patch Mountain Trail and engulfed the entire length of the trail. You can still see charred trees and burnt rhododendron lining the trail, offering an interesting look into fire ecology and resilience.\r\n\nConserving Carolina partnered with the Town of Lake Lure to protect over 1,500 acres at Buffalo Creek Park\u2014making it one of the largest local parks in North Carolina. Conserving Carolina protected this stunning tract of backcountry wilderness forever with a conservation easement and opened it to recreation for hikers and bikers alike. We designed and built the 8.6 mile trail to high standards of sustainability, in order to prevent erosion, minimize needs for future maintenance, and enhance people's experience on the trail. Our volunteer trail crews were instrumental in creating this state-of-the-art backcountry trail. The Weed Patch Mountain Trail is part of our vision for the 130-mile Hickory Nut Gorge State Trail network.\r\n\nFor more information on the Weed Patch Mountain Trail, visit the Conserving Carolina website.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7065434/breathtaking-views-from-the-grey-rock-the-halfway-point-of-the-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 4.7, "num_reviewers": 9}, "stats": {"dist": 7.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3454, 1525], "alt-change": [2459, 535], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 35.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7074377/lower-mcalpine-creek-greenway-and-mcmullen-creek-greenway", "title": "Lower McAlpine Creek Greenway and McMullen Creek Greenway", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.07661,-80.840875", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7074377", "info-text": {"description": "The Lower McAlpine Creek Greenway starts off of Pineville-Matthews Road (NC51), travels south under I-485, and concludes at Johnston Road at the intersection with Four Mile Creek Greenway.\r\n\nFrom the trailhead on Johnston Road, follow the short paved access road. To stay on McAlpine Creek Greenway, turn right to go under the Johnston Road Bridge (a left turn will take you onto Four Mile Creek Greenway). After the underpass, the greenway follows McAlpine Creek for approximately 1.4 miles before going under I-485. There are several neighborhood access points along this portion of the greenway. After I-485, the greenway circles a neighborhood before swinging back around to the north to follow McMullen Creek. The greenway goes under I-485 again and then continues for approximately 1.4 miles before ending at Pineville-Matthews Road.\r\n\nParking is available for the McAlpine Creek Greenway trailhead at 11823 Johnston Road, Charlotte, NC 28226. There is a second parking lot located at 404 Vista Grande Circle, Charlotte, NC 28226.\r\n\nParking is available for the McMullen Creek Greenway trailhead at 8135 Pineville-Matthews Rd, Charlotte, NC 28226.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7059613/lower-mcalpine-creek-greenway", "ratings": {"rating": 4.3, "num_reviewers": 6}, "stats": {"dist": 4.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [542, 523], "alt-change": [54, 51], "avg-grade": 0.0, "max-grade": 5.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7074379/four-mile-creek-greenway", "title": "Four Mile Creek Greenway", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.077786,-80.816935", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7074379", "info-text": {"description": "The Four Mile Creek Greenway starts at the intersection of Rea Road and Bevington Place and concludes at the intersection with the Lower McAlpine Creek Greenway at Johnston Road.\r\n\nFour Mile Creek Greenway in Matthews is a joint project between the Town of Matthews and Mecklenburg County that is an extremely popular destination to area residents. It is a 2.1-mile property that connects Matthews Elementary to Squirrel Lake Park to East John Street. There are several neighborhood access points along the greenway. Be sure to stop and check out the painted manhole covers and pipes and parks. Squirrel Lake Park host a large playground area, fairy trails, a lake complete with a dock and ducks and restrooms. There is also a rock feature at Fountain Rock Park with bubbling water that is irresistible to dogs and kids on the greenway. While the biking, hiking and animal loving community enjoys the greenway, wildlife such as beavers, white tailed deer and numerous bird species are also the beneficiaries of greenway.\r\n\nParking is available at Matthews Elementary School 200 W McDowell St, Matthews, NC 28105 or at Squirrel Lake Park 1631 Pleasant Plains Rd, Matthews, NC 28105.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7059608/four-mile-creek-greenway", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 1.9, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [560, 528], "alt-change": [34, 64], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 4.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7075826/gold-hill-rail-trail", "title": "Gold Hill Rail Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.513591,-80.34328", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7075826", "info-text": {"description": "Gold Hill Rail Trail begins at Miner's Field (softball field) on St. Stephens Church Road. The trail circles the ball field and then enters a wooded area, where it passes by Gold Hill Pond and the Powder House. The trail then heads back toward the town and by a few old mine shafts. The trail goes through the historic mining village, Gold Hill, NC, where many of the historic buildings have been restored as caf\u00e9s, antique shops, and museums. You can stop in E.H. Montgomery General Store to learn more about Gold Hill Rail Trail. In town, the trail crosses St. Stephens Church Road and then goes through another wooded area before two more street crossings at Old Beatty Ford Road and again at St. Stephens Church Road. After the village, the trail continues for approximately 1.5 miles. There is directional signage along the trail to assure trail users of the correct trail path.\r\n\nParking is available in the parking lot next to Miner's Field at 2439 St Stephens Church Rd, Gold Hill, North Carolina.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7058230/gold-hill-rail-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 2.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [787, 707], "alt-change": [78, 152], "avg-grade": 2.0, "max-grade": 5.0}},

Take the left fork and continue to the southern end of the property. \r\n\nAfter hitting the last berm of the run, the trail returns to the second bi-directional section. Stay to the left at the intersection and, after another tenth of a mile, the trail comes back to the first short bi-directional section. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7075824/the-falcon-trail", "title": "The Falcon Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.476495,-80.260069", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7075824", "info-text": {"description": "Connecting the Stanly County communities of Misenheimer and Richfield, The Falcon Trail offers lake and agricultural views, as well as access to Pfeiffer College and many historic buildings listed on the Natural Historic Register. There are two trail entrances, one at Richfield Park and one at the intersection of US 52 and Wesley Chapel Road in Misenheimer. Richfield Park has picnic tables and other amenities (fishing and disc golf). \r\n\nBeginning at the Richfield Park trailhead, signs mark the entrance to The Falcon Trail on the southern side of the lake. The trail is wooded and winds around Curl Tail Creek and then back towards the Richfield Park property for approximately 0.6 miles. Then, the trail crosses Richfield Lake through either a narrow covered bridge or a swinging bridge. The bridges are both adjacent to each other. The swinging bridge leads to an island with a picnic table. \r\n\nThe trail then goes back into a wooded area for approximately 0.15 miles before winding around a field. This portion of the trail offers great views of the surrounding agricultural land. After the field, the trail turns right to follow next to Culp Road for 0.3 miles. The trail crosses Culp Road at Curl Tail Creek and then follows alongside it until reaching the Pfeiffer campus near the gym. The trail follows a brief sidewalk and then enters a wooded area again near Curl Tail Creek and behind Pfeiffer's campus. The trail ends when it comes to Wesley Chapel Road.\r\n\nParking is available at the Richfield Trailhead at Richfield Park (Richfield Park Rd, Richfield, NC 28137) and at the Misenheimer entrance at the USPS (48380 US-52, Misenheimer, NC 28109).", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7058225/the-falcon-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 2.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [665, 620], "alt-change": [70, 29], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 4.0}},

This is primarily used as a mountain biking trail so expect to see some fast moving bikes on the trail and please be respectful of other users. The trail has great rolling topography with a lot of ups and downs. It is covered with loose rock for the duration of most of this trail, making it challenging to hike down but not a problem to climb. After about .4 miles you'll pass the East Fork Trail on the right. Stay to the left and continue up this trail. About 2 miles in you'll hit The Pinnacle Trail junction. The Pinnacle Trail heads out another 1.4 miles to an overlook. The West Fork Trail continues straight and after another .5 miles will reconnect with the East Fork Trail once again. This provides an opportunity to do a loop. The East Fork Trail is much less traveled than the West Fork, but is also steeper, more overgrown, and has more obstacles. \r\n\nIf you continue up the West Fork Trail it will generally terminate at the turn off to Black Rock. This steep trail climbs aggressively up to  the summit and then you can continue west to the Blue Ridge Parkway. Instead of taking the left, there is also the option of going straight. I don't think it is a formal trail but it is an old road that is still used as a trail. There is also a graveyard next to the middle intersection of the Blue/Yellow/Orange trails. \r\n\nFrom the visitor center, head south out of the parking lot and follow the Orange Trail west. After only about 0.2 mile, you'll pass two interactions with the Red Trail which heads south along the Neuse River. At the next intersection, stay straight to continue on this loop as mapped. This will take you along the eastern side of the loop. The Blue Trail, shortly followed by the Yellow Trail will split off to the left as you stay on the Orange Trail. \r\n\nThe trail turns left and heads towards the Neuse River. As it turns to parallel the water, the Yellow Trail rejoins and there will be a nice viewpoint. Continue south, the Blue Trail will also rejoin from the left. From the parking area, head north on Elk River Falls Trail for 0.1 mile. On USFS mapping, this is referred to as Big Falls. \r\n\nThe trail is very busy during summer months as the falls basin is a popular swimming hole. Please do not jump off the falls! Although the park map reports the loop length as 0.95 miles, the path will be closer to 0.80 miles if done continuously without overlapping travel on a couple of the side trails.\r\n\nThe starting point is at the highest elevation. Hiking the trail counter-clockwise (to the right at the trailhead), there is roughly a 0.5 mile intermittent descent of ~40 feet along some ridges to the lowest-lying area. At the lowest part of the trail, the creek can be crossed to access Woodland Hall Parking Lot or head back to the entrance of the park. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7005368/flat-laurel-creek-trail", "title": "Flat Laurel Creek Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.325517,-82.881982", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7005368", "info-text": {"description": "The trail begins at the Black Balsam parking area (at the end of Black Balsam Knob Road, FS816 off the Blue Ridge Parkway). This is a popular trailhead, with the possibility to make long and short loops in the area. See for example Sam's Knob Loop. The Shining Rock Wilderness lies just to the north. \r\n\nThe trail follows a railbed dating from early in the last century when the area was heavily logged. This logging lead to the peculiar \"balds\" on the tops of mountains where the forests are unable to reestablish themselves due to soil erosion. The balds offer great views though. \r\n\nNevertheless, because the trail follows an old rail bed, it descends continuously at a relatively moderate grade. (Or if hiking in the reverse direction, the moderate ascent makes it possible for us flatlanders who aren't accustomed to such altitudes not to gasp too much for air.) \r\n\nThe trail first passes through a meadow at the top of Black Balsam, but the latter half enters into the forest. The forest also features rhododendrons and berry bushes. Much of the trail can be quite rocky and technical in places due to washed out and rutted areas. There are several creek crossings as well as other areas along the trail where the water runs along the trail. Bring waterproof boots or expect to get wet feet, and expect to get a little muddy either way.  \r\n\nThere are a couple of small waterfalls visible from the trail, particularly near the end. The most notable is Wildcat Falls around the 3-mile mark, which is viewable from a concrete bridge that presumably used to be part of the railroad. Supposedly, you can also hike down to some cascades on Flat Laurel Creek around 1.6 miles in, but I didn't try it.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7007557/near-sams-knob", "ratings": {"rating": 4.4, "num_reviewers": 9}, "stats": {"dist": 3.9, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5799, 4991], "alt-change": [36, 812], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 10.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7005370/mountains-to-sea-trail-hwy-215-to-black-balsam-knob", "title": "Mountains-to-Sea Trail: Hwy 215 to Black Balsam Knob", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.304039,-82.909138", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7005370", "info-text": {"description": "This segment of the MST climbs steadily from Rt. 215 before leveling out and contouring above the Blue Ridge Parkway. The trail then climbs further to a junction with Black Balsam Knob Rd.\n\nThe Mountains-to-Sea Trail will eventually provide a foot trail across the entire state of North Carolina. Its western terminus is at one of the highest points in the state, Clingmans Dome, on the North Carolina/Tennessee state line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Its eastern end is in Jockeys Ridge State Park, near the Atlantic Ocean. It will eventually cover at least 935 miles and, as of the spring of 2008, over 400 miles of off-road footpaths were available. (The completion date for the entire trail cannot be estimated due to the need to negotiate with private landowners.) The trail will be a travel way with various sections open to hiking, mountain biking, horseback riding, and even canoeing/kayaking on a parallel paddling path. However, the entire portion of the trail within the Pisgah District is restricted to foot traffic only.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7004783/snow-covered-and-wind-blown", "ratings": {"rating": 3.8, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 4.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5960, 5130], "alt-change": [945, 190], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 22.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7016759/mountains-to-sea-trail-segment-14", "title": "Mountains-to-Sea Trail: Segment 14", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=34.581677,-78.448769", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7016759", "info-text": {"description": "Segment 14 of North Carolina's 1,175-mile Mountains-to-Sea Trail allows hikers to explore an area rich in history\u2014from the Revolutionary War to the New Deal and beyond\u2014on its route through Bladen and Pender counties.\r\n\nUnique among segments of the MST, Segment 14 also includes a short section of river that requires a boat or ferry ride. If you have access to a kayak, canoe or SUP, you can paddle the river yourself, or see the \"Northeast Cape Fear River\" section of the trail guide for information about how to find someone to ferry you.\r\n\nHighlights include:\r\n\nSingletary Lake State Park, which began its life as a park in 1936 when the National Park Service bought land for a federally financed work program and recreational demonstration project\r\nThe Elwell Ferry, one of three remaining river ferries in North Carolina\r\nThe Kelly Historical Museum, which shares the history of a community built when the Cape Fear River was the main transportation corridor in this area\r\nThe Canetuck Community Center, which is housed in a two-room school built in 1921-22 with help from the Rosenwald Fund, which funded schools for African Americans throughout the southeast US\r\nMoores Creek National Battlefield, the site of the first patriot victory in the American Revolution\r\nBurgaw, the Pender County seat, whose many historic buildings include the oldest train depot in North Carolina\r\nThe gently flowing water and abundant wildlife along a 4.5-mile stretch of the Northeast Cape Fear River \n\nThe Osgood Canal Greenway and Urban Trail in Burgaw has mileposts every quarter mile but is not marked with the MST blaze. Road portions of this segment are marked with MST blazes (a 3-inch white circle) and signs. Blazes are on the left shoulder of the road in the direction of travel, and signs are on the right side. Note that signs are often a target of theft and vandalism, and should not be relied upon exclusively for wayfinding.\r\n\nFor more information, including camping, lodging, parking, shuttles, and resupply information, as well as detailed, turn-by-turn directions, download a trail guide from the Friends of the Mountains-to-Sea Trail.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 68.4, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [63, 2], "alt-change": [323, 349], "avg-grade": 0.0, "max-grade": 3.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7048595/gully-creek-trail", "title": "Gully Creek Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=36.553458,-80.907045", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7048595", "info-text": {"description": "Start at the Cumberland Knob Recreation Center where there are nice scenic overlooks, picnic areas, and a large field perfect for family gatherings. The trail showcases beautiful plants (in the spring of the year especially) and starts here on top of the mountain. \r\n\nFrom the beginning, the trail winds down to Gully Creek on a moderately rough trail. There's no need to scramble or climb, but do watch for large roots and step-like features. Once at the bottom of the trail, you'll hike parallel to the river and over several crossings, none of which require getting too wet if at all. This part of the trail is where the magic is, as the river moves fairly rapidly and has several small waterfalls as it winds through large rocks and fallen trees. \r\n\nThere are multiple areas such as this along the trail, so don\u2019t feel as though you must take it all in at the first one you come to. After moving away from the creek, the trail starts to ascend back up the mountain. After all, what goes down must come up. The climb up is both fairly steady and steep.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7045476/spring-flowers", "ratings": {"rating": 3.3, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 2.5, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [2751, 1996], "alt-change": [747, 755], "avg-grade": 11.0, "max-grade": 27.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7053131/bubbling-spring-branch-fall-1", "title": "Bubbling Spring Branch Fall #1", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.303651,-82.909425", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7053131", "info-text": {"description": "From the Blue Ridge Parkway, head north towards Canton on NC 215 for 0.4 mile. There is a large parking area on the left (west). There is also a single vehicle parking space just past the trailhead. I recommend the larger area which gets a lot of use for those hiking the Mountains-to-Sea Trail.\r\n\nHike north on NC-215 a short distance until your see the Mountains-to-Sea Trail which is marked with a large square post and a white blaze. Follow the trail west until you cross the creek. Here the trail splits left and right; go left and follow the trail a short way until you reach a large clearing (i.e. the ground has been beat down and all the under brush is dead) with a fire pit. Proceed left at the end of the clearing and cross the creek.  \r\n\nThe trail turns right after crossing the creek and generally follows the left bank of the creek. My thanks to whomever added pink surveyor tape to help us along. Orange surveyor tape has been added to help those who may need a little more help finding the trail. Keep in mind this is the Middle Prong Wilderness area which is why the trails are not blazed better.\r\n\nDespite its beauty, the trail is not heavily used. Consequently, it will not be as wide and beat down as you may be accustomed to. The trail goes through several rhododendron \"hells\" (i.e. very dense sections of vegetation that would be impassible without a man-made path) without too much trouble. It helps you follow the path but limits the view.  \r\n\nYou are rewarded with a beautiful waterfall in a very quiet, scenic, and quintessential hideaway. \r\n\nThe path to Babbling Brook Fall #2 begins at the left of this waterfall.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Swimming \u00b7 Waterfall", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7049774/getting-my-paws-wet-at-bubbling-spring-fall-1-a-great-place-to-play-and-get-wet", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 0.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5149, 5110], "alt-change": [39, 0], "avg-grade": 3.0, "max-grade": 6.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7055145/devils-courthouse", "title": "Devil's Courthouse", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.304956,-82.899499", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7055145", "info-text": {"description": "The Devil\u2019s Courthouse, just off the Blue Ridge Parkway (BRP) at mile marker 422.4, is a must-do hike featuring a 360-degree panorama of North and South Carolina, Georgia, and Tennessee. The picnic table and bear resistant trash containers at the parking area make this an ideal spot for a leisurely snack or meal.\r\n\nThe trail follows the BRP for a short while and then proceeds into the woods. It heads up a steady ascent of approximately 290 feet. The first half of the trail is paved with benches to sit and rest. Just before the pavement ends, a connector trail comes in from the left. This unmarked connector goes over the tunnel to the Mountain-to-Sea Trail: Segment 2. \r\n\nContinue following the paved trail up towards the summit. You'll see several small paths off to the left that have been created by visitors leaving the main trail to see the views along the way. Once the pavement ends, the tail turns to rock with several rock staircases with railings. You'll pop out of the woods to the summit with spectacular panoramic views. There are two markers at the top that point out the various mountains surrounding you. \r\n\nThe return trip is simple; just go back the way you came. Make sure you stay on the asphalt to avoid the connector trail to the MST.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7053844/view-from-the-summit-of-devils-courthouse", "ratings": {"rating": 4.3, "num_reviewers": 9}, "stats": {"dist": 0.5, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5751, 5463], "alt-change": [288, 0], "avg-grade": 12.0, "max-grade": 22.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7087919/harrisburg-extension-loop", "title": "Harrisburg Extension Loop", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.315995,-80.659047", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7087919", "info-text": {"description": "This trail starts off of the Harrisburg Ball Field Loop directly past the Pepsi scoreboard. Descend the small hill past the fire road on the right. The trail starts off to the right a few feet after the fire road and is marked with blue and white ribbons. At the 0.2 mile mark the trail takes a quick right hand turn after a short downhill and immediately crosses a creek. After the creek crossing, the trail climbs fairly steeply through the only major climb in the clockwise direction. After the trail comes out of the woods, stay to the left and follow the pink flags for a short downhill section that runs parallel to the train tracks that concludes at another creek crossing at the 0.5 mile mark.  \r\n\nOnce you pass the crossing, there is a small optional loop on the left. At the 0.7 mile mark, the trail makes a quick 180 degree turn to the left and follows the levee 0.1 mile before dropping back down into the woods on the right. The trail climbs up to its highest point at the mile mark and leads to the main downhill section that concludes at the 1.2 mile mark at another creek crossing.  \r\n\nAfter the crossing, take a right at the fire road and traverse another rocky garden section before the trail opens up in a small grassy area. Stay to the right by the tree line as the trail takes a left back into the woods shortly after narrowing back to doubletrack. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7019293/old-butt-knob-trail-100", "title": "Old Butt Knob Trail #100", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.358506,-82.821175", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7019293", "info-text": {"description": "This trail is not blazed, so be sure to bring the Hiking Project mobile app to find your way. If you leave and return to the creek without finding it, you've gone too far.\r\n\nOnce on the trail, it is a steady climb for the first couple of miles to get up to the ridgeline. If you do this trail in the winter, expect to have good views the whole way, but in summer or fall, they're bound to be obscured by the foliage. Once you have reached the ridgeline, the trail will level out and the hiking will be much easier. You'll go over a few knobs, where the forest opens up, before eventually reaching the access trail to Shining Rock (a very large quartz outcropping) that makes a great lunch spot with expansive views. Like many trails in that area, it is a bit rugged and not too maintained. I love that. Others may not. Not one person was spotted on this trail during the peak of fall colors, while there were flocks on other trails in the area. \r\n\nThe views are fantastic from the ridge line, the colors were amazing, and there's a wonderful sense of stillness and wild along this trail. \r\n\nThere is an invigorating river crossing to start the climb. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7053586/murrays-mill-pond-loop-trail", "title": "Murray's Mill Pond Loop Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.676186,-81.093481", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7053586", "info-text": {"description": "The trail starts by crossing the old bridge next to Murray's Mill. Hike up the hill and through the grindstones, turning right to stay by the mill pond. The brick house on your left, built in 1935, belonged to Lloyd Murray, the last of the Murray Family to operate the mill. The small white house is the newest building on the property and was built in 1950 for Lloyd's son Bill and his wife Mary Sue. The large white house is the George Huffman House, built in 1820. It was moved to the property in 1998.\r\n\nThrough a small patch of woods, the trail continues along the edge of the farmer's field, across a foot bridge and into the woods. Major obstacles in this area are roots and small stumps in the trail. After crossing a second footbridge, look to the water on your right. This part of the pond is home to a great blue heron, beavers, & many frogs.\r\n\nOut of the woods you again follow the edge of the farmer's field to a boardwalk on your right that crosses the marsh. This ends at the back of Shiloh Methodist Church cemetery. John Murray and his family are near the top of the hill on the left.\r\n\nThe trail continues to the right. Note: this section can be flooded when water is high. The end of this section deposits you on Shiloh Rd. You'll need to cross the creek on the car bridge. Follow the road, then turn right through the fence opening into the field.\r\n\nThe second half of the trail follows the dirt/grass road around the farmer's field. It is completely in the sun. Once around the field, cross the stone/grass causeway and up the hill towards the white barn. Turn right before the barn on the gravel road and follow around the field past old outbuildings. At the wheathouse you can take the stairs down by the mill for a shortcut (if the gate is open) or continue to follow the gravel road around the field, then through the gate and make a right down the driveway to the parking lot.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7050314/view-of-murrays-mill-from-the-start-of-the-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 1.8, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [910, 888], "alt-change": [61, 57], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 4.0}},

The first part of the trail is fairly flat; there are a few ground hazards here and there but you can circumvent these. Once you emerge from the treeline you'll traverse an open field past a landscaped treeline and then around sidewalk railings at the school buildings. You'll continue through a landscaped gully and over more open field until you cross a road and enter woods where the main loop is. \r\n\nYou'll have some descent before picking which way to run the loop. Following the recorded trail to the left, you'll have a fairly easy hike until the trail meets up with the ICC Trail System's Yellow Trail. You'll hike on a small segment of the Yellow Trail, climbing down to cross a foot bridge and then climbing up the other side until you veer right off the Yellow Trail and back on to the Orange Trail. \r\n\nThis part of the trail is a fairly easy hike, though you'll have to watch the occasional thorn branches that a grown across the path like small tripwires. The trail will open up into some thorny bushes on each side until meets back up to the loop start. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7015748/mountains-to-sea-trail-segment-2", "title": "Mountains-to-Sea Trail: Segment 2", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.460539,-83.140472", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7015748", "info-text": {"description": "This segment, located in one of the most biodiverse areas of the world, showcases that diversity. Nearly all the major plant communities of the southern Appalachians are represented, from spruce-fir forests typically found in Canada to rich cove forests, and from rhododendron thickets to heath balds\u2014 and even a little of the rare spray cliff community. Around every corner is a view greater than the one before it. And the myriad streams and waterfalls provide delightful coolness even on the hottest summer day.\r\n\nAlthough it parallels the Blue Ridge Parkway and can generally be accessed from the Parkway, most of Segment 2 is in the Nantahala and Pisgah National Forests. With the exception of the trail within the Middle Prong Wilderness Area, the MST in Segment 2 is generally well marked with white blazes, either painted on or affixed to trees or signposts. Within the Wilderness Area (EB Miles 37.7 to 42.3, WB Miles 21.4 to 25.9), blazes are not permitted. Throughout this segment, the tread of the trail can be indistinct and difficult to follow in places.\r\n\nHighlights include:\r\n\u2022\tThe four-state views from Waterrock Knob, at 6,292 feet, is the highest point on Segment 2 and the third-highest point on the entire MST\r\n\u2022\tSkinny Dip Falls, a popular waterfall and swimming hole\r\n\u2022\tThe nearly trackless expanse of the Middle Prong Wilderness Area\r\n\u2022\tThe views over the ghost forest of Graveyard Fields\r\n\u2022\tThe tourist haven of the Pisgah Inn, with its famous restaurant\r\n\nFor more information, including camping, lodging, parking, shuttles, and resupply information, as well as detailed, turn-by-turn directions, download a trail guide from the Friends of the Mountains-to-Sea Trail.\r\n\nThe trail in this segment is maintained by the Carolina Mountain Club.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Swimming \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7014035/rays-and-ridges-from-waterrock-knob-photo-by-robert-stephens", "ratings": {"rating": 4.3, "num_reviewers": 8}, "stats": {"dist": 62.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5953, 3348], "alt-change": [9056, 9927], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 60.0}},

Proceed through the picnic shelter and playground area, past the bath house. Don't let the kids stop here, or you'll never do the full trail. The playground is the reward for after the hike! Bath house closes in the winter. The trail takes off behind the bath house.\r\n\nThere is an A loop and a B loop and they form a figure eight, so you can go either way. I prefer going to the left because it's all downhill (wink, wink, nod). At the intersection of the loops, stay left. Continue on until you come to a road crossing. Cross the road and proceed. Several areas are low and swampy so good shoes help. \r\n\nSomewhere along the way is a bamboo grove. Fun for the kids to hide in, but please don't leave them there. Pack out what you pack in. \r\n\nAfter about two miles, you'll come to a small bridge crossing the river and opening up to a field and gravel round. This is where this map turns around and goes back the way you came. If you would like to finish the trail for a total of approximately 2.5 miles, then proceed up the gravel road where the trail will pick up again. You'll once again come to the intersection of the two loops. Stay to your left and make your way back to the top where the playground is located. At the start of the trail, take the right fork and follow the loop in the counterclockwise direction. This section of trail is very well built and almost every significant turn is bermed for bikes. \r\n\nAs the trail continues on to the end, it crosses over three wooden bridges and one fairly difficult creek crossing. After the third bridge, the trail splits into a short, rocky loop that can be repeated or bypassed depending on the hiker. To access the most technical part of the system, take a right when the trail forks to hike the tricky rock section or take the left option to bypass it. The trail begins at the trailhead on McNeely Road. There are four picnic tables along the 250 foot paved walkway at the trailhead. \r\n\nAfter going down a slight gravel incline to enter the trail, you begin to follow the Wolf and Bates Branch Creeks. There are benches and horse hitching rails along the trail. There are also a few small wooden bridges, but there are trails for horseback riders and beginner mountain bikers to go around these bridges. The entirety of the trail is shaded and there are a few slight inclines as the trail meanders through the woods. The trail currently ends at a dry creek near the northernmost end of the property.\r\n\nCatawba Lands Conservancy, in partnership with the Town of Mineral Springs and the NC Clean Water Management Trust Fund, protects the 60 acres of hardwood forest along the trail and creek.\r\n\nParking address and trailhead location: 6214 McNeely Rd, Waxhaw, NC 28173.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7057934/mineral-springs-greenway", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 1.8, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [602, 529], "alt-change": [6, 79], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 3.0}},

From this entrance, you can either go south for approximately 1 mile or north for approximately 2.3 miles. If you choose to go south, you'll take a right after entering the trail. There is a swinging-bridge soon after beginning this portion of the trail. The trail winds around a wooded area along Forney Creek before ending at Optimist Club Road. If you choose to go north, you'll take a left after entering the trail.\r\n\nThe trail goes through a 310-acre Forney Creek Conservation Area that is protected by Catawba Lands Conservancy and the North Carolina Clean Water Management Trust Fund. The northern trail will take you past two waterfowl impoundments once used by the Catawba Springs Hunt Club. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7089445/alexanders-ford", "title": "Alexander's Ford", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.314713,-82.039245", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7089445", "info-text": {"description": "Alexander's Ford is an easy 1.3 mile jaunt in Rutherford County that allows hikers to step into history. The volunteer patriot army followed this path and camped on this land the night before the infamous Battle of Kings Mountain, which proved to be a turning point of the Revolutionary War. This trail is largely flat and on an even surface, making it a trail friendly to all hikers of all experience levels. The stage this land set for important events in the Revolutionary War also attracts history buffs from all over. \r\nEvery autumn, re-enactors travel the 330-mile route of the Overmountain Men, as the original patriot militia came to be known, camping in the same locations and following the same trails and roads. \r\n\nThe Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail stretches through four states (Virginia, Tennessee, North and South Carolina), ending at the site of the pivotal Kings Mountain battle. About 87 miles is now open to walk. Conserving Carolina and Polk County Community Foundation facilitated permanent conservation and public ownership of 162 acres to create the Bradley Nature Preserve at Alexander's Ford in 2012. The Preserve includes the trail and the site of the militia's encampment on the banks of the river, just prior to their victory at the Battle of Kings Mountain, the turning point of the Revolutionary War.", "features": "Historical Significance \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7065404/the-trail-quietly-winds-through-alexanders-ford", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 1.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [937, 757], "alt-change": [14, 193], "avg-grade": 3.0, "max-grade": 9.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7089571/florence-nature-preserve-access-trail", "title": "Florence Nature Preserve Access Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.473459,-82.33224", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7089571", "info-text": {"description": "This trail begins at the Upper Hickory Nut Gorge Trailhead parking area and gains elevation quickly.  Follow the numbered yellow blazes to stay on track. There are several locust log staircases that switchback up for the first quarter mile of trail. The trail evens out after you pass a dilapidated shack, the remains of an old homesite. You'll eventually intersect the Blue Trail, one of the many trails that makeup the network of Florence Nature Preserve.\r\n\nDr. Tom Florence and his wife Glenna left a legacy of natural wonders when they donated their 600 acre property on Little Pisgah Mountain to Conserving Carolina. The couple started acquiring this land on the southern slopes of the mountain in the 1960s and they made regular trips from Georgia to enjoy it. In their retirement, they lived on the land for 20 years. They came to have a deep sense of connection to the land, and they didn't want its natural treasures ever to be lost. And they didn't want to just keep them to themselves.\r\n\nThe Florences donated 300 acres to Conserving Carolina in 1996, which was the first property that the land trust owned. They went on to donate an additional 300 acres in 2001. Conserving Carolina adopted and improved nearly five miles of existing trails and has opened the land to the public as the Florence Nature Preserve.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7066509/there-is-a-significant-climb-as-you-enter-the-preserve-with-lots-of-locust-log-s", "ratings": {"rating": 3.7, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 0.8, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2906, 2457], "alt-change": [457, 8], "avg-grade": 11.0, "max-grade": 23.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7089619/blue-trail", "title": "Blue Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.493722,-82.33718", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7089619", "info-text": {"description": "This trail begins at the end of the Florence Nature Preserve Access Trail, introducing the hiker to several miles of beautiful trails in the Preserve. The Florence Nature Preserve Access Trail intersects the blue trail near its middle, allowing you to go right or left. Turning left will lead you on the fastest route to Rattlesnake Knob, a gorgeous view within the Preserve. Turning right will lead you winding down a tributary of Hickory Creek, where you can see several small waterfalls and enjoy the sound of the babbling brook. This trail can be steep in places, but is largely easy to maneuver and friendly to all hiking experience levels!\r\n\nDr. Tom Florence and his wife Glenna left a legacy of natural wonders when they donated their 600 acre property on Little Pisgah Mountain to Conserving Carolina. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7089623/yellow-trail", "title": "Yellow Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.488031,-82.334899", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7089623", "info-text": {"description": "This short trail connects the White Trail and the Blue Trail for hikers desiring a slightly shorter hike. It gets steep in some sections, but this trail is still recommended for all hikers. The trail wanders amongst the rhododendron and mountain laurels that populate this area, and ends at a tributary that feeds into Hickory Creek. It's the perfect place to go for a quiet and pleasant hike in the woods, off the beaten path. This land is home to many special plants and wildlife, from pink and yellow ladyslippers to rare salamanders. Keep your eyes open, and you never know what you might see! \r\n\nDr. Tom Florence and his wife Glenna left a legacy of natural wonders when they donated their 600 acre property on Little Pisgah Mountain to Conserving Carolina. The couple started acquiring this land on the southern slopes of the mountain in the 1960s and they made regular trips from Georgia to enjoy it. In their retirement, they lived on the land for 20 years. They came to have a deep sense of connection to the land, and they didn't want its natural treasures ever to be lost. And they didn't want to just keep them to themselves.\r\n\nThe Florences donated 300 acres to Conserving Carolina in 1996, which was the first property that the land trust owned. They went on to donate an additional 300 acres in 2001. Conserving Carolina adopted and improved nearly five miles of existing trails and has opened the land to the public as the Florence Nature Preserve.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7066512/take-a-peaceful-stroll-through-the-woods", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3271, 3088], "alt-change": [0, 183], "avg-grade": 12.0, "max-grade": 26.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7089907/norman-wilder-trail-blue", "title": "Norman Wilder Trail (Blue)", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.224567,-82.274325", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7089907", "info-text": {"description": "This short trail leads you from the small parking area just off of Highway 176 and into the preserve. The trail begins by an information kiosk, and gradually inclines. Around the halfway point, the trail follows a private driveway for 300 yards. A second informational kiosk directs you back onto the trail, where it will intersect with the Drip Falls Trail (Yellow) and the Cliffs Trail (Red) shortly after.\r\n\nNorman Wilder Forest is a 185-acre preserve between Saluda and Tryon. As you explore the hiking trails, you'll find yourself surrounded by mature forests with majestic, tall trees. In the spring and summer, you can enjoy exceptional displays of wildflowers. The preserve is part of the North Carolina Birding Trail and home to many species including wood warblers, thrushes, and tanagers. Beautiful mountain streams flow through on their way to the North Pacolet River.\r\n\nConserving Carolina owns Norman Wilder Forest and is committed to maintaining it as a nature preserve for generations to come. The 185 acres of Norman Wilder Forest were acquired in 1999 by the Pacolet Area Conservancy, one of two land trusts that merged in 2017 to form Conserving Carolina. The forest was named for a lifelong conservationist and environmental educator who served on the board of the Pacolet Area Conservancy.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Geological Significance \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 0.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1274, 1009], "alt-change": [273, 15], "avg-grade": 8.0, "max-grade": 14.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7090316/nature-park-trail", "title": "Nature Park Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.311605,-82.48587", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7090316", "info-text": {"description": "This trail offers scenic views of Rhododendron Lake and a fun river crossing across several stones. The trail is largely flat, and users can make their walk as long or as short as they like. Look out for pooling water after a heavy rain.\r\n\nRhododendron Lake Nature Park is a 10-acre park nestled between Lake Drive and Primrose Lane, conveniently accessible from both Laurel Park Highway and White Pine Drive. It features almost a mile of walking paths, fitness stations, a catch-and-release fishing pond, picnic area with charcoal grill, and more.\r\n\nRhododendron Lake was a major community hub in the 1950s and 1960s in Hendersonville. The Red Cross held swim lessons for residents, so many people took their first swim strokes in that lake. In the 1980s, however, the earthen dam that was set to protect the surrounding residents from the Lake was found to be unsound. The lake size reduced from nine acres to one acre and the site where so many used to congregate and enjoy each other's company became overgrown and forgotten by many.\r\n\nThe new Rhododendron Lake Nature Park seeks to preserve and remind residents of those memories. Through the help of our donors and grants, we were able to construct a park that will make room to create new memories and bring the community together the same way its predecessor did.", "features": "Lake", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7066504/a-fun-water-crossing-over-stone-steps", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.4, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2210, 2187], "alt-change": [24, 12], "avg-grade": 2.0, "max-grade": 4.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7091831/rough-creek-inner-loop", "title": "Rough Creek Inner Loop", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.592829,-82.849436", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7091831", "info-text": {"description": "I don't know if I've ever come across an area with so many consistent wildflowers throughout the year, and you are pretty much guaranteed to have the place to yourself. \r\n\nAfter the steep climb up the access trail, things mellow out on this loop. The trail follows an old forest road with gentle grades and is easy to follow. Simply always stay to the left of any intersection if hiking counterclockwise. This is the innermost loop/trail. Taking a right will spin you out further into the trail system. Staying to the left on the forestry road will keep you on this loop. Use the Hiking Project mobile app if you have any concerns.\r\n\nThe trail is heavily forested with a splendid mix of hardwoods, and some softwoods, and an ever-present assortment of wildflowers (the most amazing trillium display in Spring, particularly on the adjacent Cherry Cove Trail). This is an infrequently used set of trails and rarely is anyone else out there. A benefit of being a bit out of the way. \r\n\nThe trail can hold water in spots and get a bit muddy, but rarely is it problematic. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7093265/cherry-cove-trail", "title": "Cherry Cove Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.610797,-82.841791", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7093265", "info-text": {"description": "Starting from the outer loop of the rough creek trail system, this trail starts when that loop/old forestry road hits a gate and there is a sign to the left that marks the beginning of the Cherry Cove Trail. \r\n\nThe trail enters the forest and is a soft and gentle singletrack meandering through the forest. In the spring, the trillium here are like nowhere else. Early summer, the blackberries are everywhere. \r\n\nThe trail is in two sections; the upper and the lower. The upper rolls up and down through the forest from the starting point mentioned. It goes for a little over a mile. The best view in this system is close to the end of this upper section as it hits a switchback turning to the right. To the left, at that switchback, you'll see a faint trail going to a rocky outcropping. This is an amazing place for a mid-run snack (it is almost all downhill from this point) and/or to simply enjoy the view. \r\n\nAfter the switchback, the trail reconnects with the forestry road. Turn left and a quarter of a mile down (if that) the Cherry Cove Trail re-enters the forest. This \"lower\" section is a great downhill stretch of just around 1 mile in length. It is another perfect singletrack that drops through pristine eastern hardwood forest.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 2.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [4410, 3979], "alt-change": [174, 483], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 13.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7102987/beaver-lake-perimeter-trail", "title": "Beaver Lake Perimeter Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.636092,-82.568901", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7102987", "info-text": {"description": "The trail follows the shore of Beaver Lake in North Asheville. With a parking lot at the northwest corner of the lake and a lot by the bird sanctuary at the east end of the lake, the trail goes through neighborhood roads, open singletrack, and canopied dirt and gravel trails. There are a number of terrain changes, from paved road to gravel to rooty and rocky singletrack, this trail is manageable for beginner runners who can watch their step, but not possible for a stroller. \r\n\nThere are a few steep elevation changes, but most of the shore is relatively flat with the occasional gradual incline as you move toward or away from the water. \r\n\nIt has amazing views of the beautiful and historic neighborhood in addition to the view of the lake and the surrounding mountains. The change from the neighborhood along Glen Falls and Lakeview Dr, the open shoreline closer to Merrimon, the forested bird sanctuary, and the run along Merrimon provides a surprising amount of variety for a two-mile run. \r\n\nIf you park at the northwest lot off Glen Falls, you have the option of just running a figure-eight loop next to Merrimon that circles the fields between Merrimon and the lake, or you can do the loop around the whole lake. \r\n\nNote that, if you take the loop around the whole lake, you'll have to run about 40 meters from the Bird Sanctuary parking lot, onto the shoulder or Merrimon Ave, to link back up to the singletrack path in the park. \r\n\nAlternatively, you can start at the bird sanctuary, head out south through the Perimeter Trail leading into the woods and use the loop in the grassy part and head back (as an out-and-back, avoiding running on the grass next to Merrimon), making it more like a 4+ mile out-and-back.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 1.9, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [2111, 2098], "alt-change": [36, 34], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 2.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7010211/at-smoky-mountain-hiking-club-tnnc", "title": "AT: Smoky Mountain Hiking Club (TN/NC)", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=35.331548,-83.592145", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7010211", "info-text": {"description": "This trail is for the serious hiker that wants to spend multiple days in the park experiencing some of the best it has to offer.  \r\n\nBeginning in the south at Fontana Dam, you begin with a steep climb up to the ridgeline that will check your fitness for the rest of the hike. But you are quickly rewarded with a break and a view at Shuckstack Fire Tower a little over 4 miles in. Climb the tower, one of four fire towers in the park, for spectacular views of Fontana Lake to the south.\r\n\nContinue your ascent over the rest of your day to either Mollies Ridge Shelter (10.7 miles in), Russell Field Shelter (13.5 miles in), or Spence Field Shelter (16.4 miles in). Don't be surprised to encounter a bear or two in this area, especially around Spence Field\u2014a real and beautiful field where I had my first talk with a bear who was pretty unhappy; I was attempting to use the same bush he was eating from to take care of business... Needless to say I found a different spot.\r\n\nLeaving Spence Field brings you to a sequence of vistas, the most famous and incredible of which is Rocky Top. On a clear day, the 360-degree view stretches on for miles. On a more typical Smoky Mountain morning covered in dense fog, you feel as though you have found a secret passage up into the clouds as you emerge from a tunnel of mountain laurel onto the bare and rocky peak.  Following Rocky Top are many more balds, gaps, and other viewpoints worth taking a short break at to soak in the view.  \r\n\nLeaving the gaps and a string of well-built shelters brings you to perhaps the most iconic part of the trail as well as the highest point of the AT\u2014Clingman's Dome. Pray for the typical mountain fog to clear as you climb the observation tower (along with the better-smelling visitors who parked a mile away) for spectacular views. Descend among the firs into a beautiful old growth forest before coming to Newfound Gap, the easiest place to hitchhike to Tennessean or Carolinian civilization.\r\n\nThe shorter northern half of the park offers two more must-sees\u2014Charlie's Bunion, a spectacular rock outcropping, and Mt. Cammerer/Sharp Top Fire Tower, the only stone Western-style fire tower in the park (like a lighthouse on a mountain). The pattern of well-built shelters with comfortable wooden bunks continues throughout the trail. So does the flora, so keep your eyes peeled for trillium, violets, and irises. If you feel like extending your hike, cut down the mountain to the Big Creek Trail for Midnight Hole.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Commonly Backpacked \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7014495/plenty-of-mountains-to-view-from-clingmans-dome", "ratings": {"rating": 4.7, "num_reviewers": 14}, "stats": {"dist": 102.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [6625, 1701], "alt-change": [22301, 22017], "avg-grade": 8.0, "max-grade": 49.0}},
